title: Corbett v. Weaver
description: The Court of Appeals affirmed the trial court's denial of a motion for a directed verdict and a motion for a new trial.  The appellant argued the evidence presented at trial supported the respondent's liability under the family purpose doctrine.  The trial court found conflicting evidence was presented and sent the issue to the jury.  The Court of Appeals agreed and, therefore, found no error in the trial court's rulings.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Ted Corbett, Appellant,
        v.
        Jordan William
          Weaver and Michael Joel Weaver, Defendants,
        Of Whom Michael
          Joel Weaver is the Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â Daniel F. Pieper, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4440
  Heard September 16, 2008 â€“ Filed October 7,
2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        E. Leroy Nettles, Sr. and Marian D.
          Nettles, both of Lake City, for Appellant.
        Robert Brown, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.:Â 
  Ted Corbett (Corbett) brought a negligence action against Jordan William Weaver
  (Jordan) and Michael Joel Weaver (Michael) following a motor vehicle accident.Â 
  Corbett asserted Jordan was negligent and sought to assert liability against
  Michael under the family purpose doctrine.Â  The trial court denied Corbettâ€™s
  motion for a directed verdict as to the applicability of the family purpose
  doctrine and his motion for a new trial.Â  Corbett appeals the trial courtâ€™s
  rulings.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
On April 27, 2004, sixteen-year-old Jordan was driving a 1994 Jeep
  Wrangler to NAPA Auto Parts to purchase an auto part for his father, Michael. Â As
  Jordan was returning to the family home in Timmonsville, South Carolina, he
  approached a T-intersection with a stop sign.Â  Jordan testified he stopped at
  the stop sign and looked twice in both directions before turning left onto the
  main road.Â  At the same time, Corbett was traveling in a northeasterly
  direction on the main road.Â  As Jordan attempted to turn left onto the main
  road, the front passenger side of his Jeep collided with Corbettâ€™s vehicle.Â  Corbettâ€™s vehicle rolled several times rendering him a paraplegic.Â  Â Â 
Thereafter, Corbett commenced an action against Jordan and Michael (collectively â€œthe Weaversâ€) based on the family purpose doctrine.Â  While
  Jordan admitted liability based on his negligence, Michael contested
  liability arguing the family purpose doctrine did not apply. Â Â 
At trial, it was stipulated that the case would be tried on two
  issues: (1) the amount of damages Corbett was entitled to and (2) whether
  Michael was liable pursuant to the family purpose doctrine.Â Â Â  Â Â Â 
During trial, Jordan testified[1] he normally drove the Jeep and used the Jeep to transport his brother to their
  school.Â  In addition, Jordan stated his father gave the Jeep to him as a gift
  several months before he received his driverâ€™s license. 
Michael also testified regarding the ownership and use of the Jeep,
  which was titled in his name.Â  He stated Jordan lived at home on the date of
  the accident and was going to NAPA Auto Parts to purchase a part for Michael
  before the accident occurred.Â  Michael also stated he owned three personal
  vehicles, including the Jeep, and these vehicles were for his use, his wifeâ€™s
  use, and his childrenâ€™s use.Â  However, Michael also testified the Jeep was a
  present to Jordan, as Jordan drove the Jeep more than any of the other family
  vehicles.Â  Â Â 
After the Weavers rested, Corbett moved for a directed verdict based
  on the family purpose doctrine.Â  Corbett argued Michael purchased the Jeep, the
  Jeep was titled in Michaelâ€™s name, Jordan was running an errand for Michael at
  the time of the accident, and the overall use of the vehicle was for family
  purposes, so Michael, as Jordanâ€™s father, should be vicariously liable for Jordanâ€™s actions.Â  The trial court denied Corbettâ€™s motion finding conflicting
  testimony was introduced regarding the ownership of the Jeep such that a jury
  question existed as to whether the family purpose doctrine applied. Â The trial
  court charged the jury and specifically discussed the family purpose doctrine.Â 
  Thereafter, the jury returned a verdict awarding $2,000,000 in actual damages
  against Jordan but found in favor of Michael and thus awarded no damages
  against him.Â  Corbett made a post-trial motion for a new trial, which the trial
  court denied.Â  This appeal follows.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. DIRECTED VERDICT MOTION
â€œIn
  deciding whether to grant or deny a directed verdict motion, the trial court is
  concerned only with the existence or non-existence of evidence.â€Â  Sims v.
    Giles, 343 S.C. 708, 714, 541 S.E.2d 857, 861 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The trial
  court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the nonmoving
  party.Â  Id. at 714, 541 S.E.2d at 860.Â  If the evidence as a whole is
  susceptible to more than one reasonable inference, the case should be submitted
  to the jury.Â  Pond Place Partners, Inc. v. Poole, 351 S.C. 1, 15, 567
  S.E.2d 881, 888 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
When
  reviewing the denial of a motion for directed verdict, this Court must apply
  the same standard and view the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the
  light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Id.Â  â€œWhen considering
  directed verdict motions, neither the trial court nor the appellate court has
  authority to decide credibility issues or to resolve conflicts in the testimony
  or evidence.â€Â  Estate of Carr ex rel. Bolton v. Circle S Enters., Inc.,
  379 S.C. 31, 39, 664 S.E.2d 83, 86 (Ct. App. 2008).Â  The trial court can only
  be reversed by this Court when no evidence supports the ruling below or when
  the ruling is controlled by an error of law.Â  Law v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr.,
  368 S.C. 424, 434-35, 629 S.E.2d 642, 648 (2006).Â  
At
  trial, Corbett moved for a directed verdict regarding Michaelâ€™s liability
  pursuant to the family purpose doctrine.Â  For the family purpose doctrine to
  apply, the following elements must be proven: (1) the defendant is the head of
  the family; (2) the defendant owns, furnishes, and maintains a vehicle; (3) the
  vehicle is for the general use and convenience of the family; (4) the family
  member has general authority to operate the vehicle for those purposes; and (5)
  the family member was negligent in the use of the vehicle.Â  Evans v. Stewart,
  370 S.C. 522, 527, 636 S.E.2d 632, 635 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  The applicability of
  the family purpose doctrine is generally a question of fact for the jury to
  decide, unless no factual issue exists, therefore, making its applicability an
  issue of law for the trial judge to determine.Â  Id.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In
  support of his directed verdict motion, Corbett argued the testimony at trial
  supported Michaelâ€™s liability under the family purpose doctrine.Â  Corbett
  argued that Michael was the owner of the vehicle because he purchased and had
  title to the Jeep.Â  He also argued in the alternative that although Michael had
  given Jordan the Jeep, it was still used for family purposes.Â  Corbett also
  made the argument that â€œ[a] young person canâ€™t own a vehicle.â€Â  In response to
  Corbettâ€™s arguments, the Weavers argued there was evidence that Jordan owned the Jeep.Â  Michael and Jordan both testified the Jeep was a gift from Michael
  to Jordan.Â Â Â Â Â  
Viewing
  the evidence in the light most favorable to Michael, a jury issue existed
  regarding the ownership of the Jeep.Â  The trial court was presented with
  conflicting evidence concerning ownership of the Jeep, allowing for two
  reasonable inferences about which party was the owner of the Jeep.Â  The Jeep
  being titled in Michaelâ€™s name was not conclusive evidence Michael was the
  owner of the Jeep, because title alone is not dispositive of ownership.Â  See id., at 528, 636 S.E.2d at 636 (explaining a vehicle titled in oneâ€™s
  name is not always indicative of ownership of that vehicle).Â  Furthermore,
  because there was evidence the Jeep was not provided by Michael for the general
  use and convenience of the family but rather was a gift to Jordan, a question of fact existed as to whether Michael should be held liable under the
  family purpose doctrine.Â  See Thompson v. Michael, 315 S.C. 268,
  273, 433 S.E.2d 853, 856 (1993) (â€œSince there is evidence the car was not
  provided by [the father who is the title-owner] for the general use and
  convenience of the family but rather was a gift to [the driverâ€™s sister], a
  question of fact exists whether [the father] is liable under the family purpose
  doctrine.â€). 
One
  of the elements that must be proven for the family purpose doctrine to apply is
  that the head of the household owns the vehicle.Â  Evans, 370 S.C. at 527, 636 S.E.2d at 635.Â  With the conflicting evidence, ownership was a proper
  issue for the jury to determine, making the trial courtâ€™s decision to deny the
  directed verdict motion proper.Â  Pond Place Partners, Inc.,Â  351 S.C. at 15, 567 S.E.2d at 888 (â€œIf the evidence as
  a whole is susceptible of more than one reasonable inference, the case should
  be submitted to the jury.â€).Â  Â Â Â Â 
II. MOTION FOR A NEW TRIAL 
A
  trial courtâ€™s order granting or denying a new trial upon the facts will not be
  disturbed unless its decision is wholly unsupported by the evidence or the conclusion
  was controlled by an error of law. Â Folkens v. Hunt, 300 S.C. 251,
  254-55, 387 S.E.2d 265, 267 (1990). Â When an order pertaining to a new trial is
  before this Court, our review is limited to the consideration of whether
  evidence exists to support the trial courtâ€™s order.Â  Id. at 255, 387
  S.E.2d at 267.Â  
As
  explained above, the record contains conflicting evidence as to who owned the
  Jeep, which was the basis for the trial court sending that issue to the jury. Â There
  was evidence Michael owned the Jeep, but there was also evidence Jordan owned the Jeep because it was a gift.Â  The jury was required to make the decision as
  to who was the owner and decided Jordan was the owner of the Jeep.Â  Sufficient
  evidence in the record supports this finding, which makes the trial courtâ€™s
  denial of Corbettâ€™s motion for a new trial proper.Â  See Proctor v.
    Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 368 S.C. 279, 293, 628 S.E.2d 496,
  504 (Ct. App. 2006) (stating if there is any evidence that could support the
  juryâ€™s findings, a motion for a new trial is properly denied).Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
Based on the
  foregoing, the trial courtâ€™s decision to deny the motion for a directed verdict
  and the motion for a new trial isÂ  Â 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON and KONDUROS, JJ.,
  concur.Â  

[1] Because both parties stipulated the issue of
  liability and were only litigating the issues of damages and the applicability
  of the family purpose doctrine, the testimony references for Jordan and Michael
  are excerpts from Jordan and Michaelâ€™s depositions, which were submitted into
evidence during trial.

title: Ardis v. Combined Insurance Company
description: In this Workers' Compensation action, the Court of Appeals affirmed a lump sum award and burial expenses to the decedent employee's beneficiaries, finding the employee's death arose in the scope and course of his employment.  Because the employee died while sleeping in the hotel where the out-of-town seminar took place and the room was paid for and reserved by his employer, the fact that the seminar had ended several hours earlier that afternoon was not enough to take the employee's death outside the course of employment for purposes of compensation under the Workers' Compensation Act.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Kevin Wayne
          Ardis (Deceased), Employee, Respondent,
        v.
        Combined
          Insurance Company, Employer, and Cambridge Integrated Services Group, Inc.,
          Carrier, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
  Â R. Ferrell Cothran, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge

Opinion No. 4441 
  Heard September 18, 2008 â€“ Filed October
14, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        James H. Lichty, Weston Adams, III and Ashley B. Stratton, of Columbia, for Appellants.
        William Ceth Land, of
          Manning, for Respondent.
      
    
  


GEATHERS,
  J.: In this Workersâ€™ Compensation
  action, Combined Insurance Company (Combined) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s
  affirmance of an order of the Appellate Panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation
  Commission (the Commission) granting a lump sum award and burial expenses to
  the beneficiaries of Kevin Ardis (Ardis).Â  On appeal, Combined argues Mr.
  Ardisâ€™ death occurred outside the scope and course of his employment, thus
  precluding compensation under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act (the
  Act).Â  We affirm. 
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
At the time of
  Ardisâ€™ death, he was employed by Combined as an insurance sales representative.Â  As an
  employee, Ardis attended a regional sales meeting from January 13-15, 2006, at
  the Holiday Inn in Marietta, Georgia.Â  On Friday, January 13, Ardis and his
  girlfriend, Alicia Connor (Connor), drove approximately five hours from their
  hometown in Wedgefield, South Carolina to Marietta. Â On Friday evening, they
  checked into the Holiday Inn where the sales meeting was to take place the
  following day from 10:00 a.m. until 3:00 p.m.Â  
Kevin Ristau (Ristau), a regional manager for
  Combined, testified his assistant booked Ardisâ€™ room at the Holiday Inn. Â Ristau also stated employees had the option
  of staying one or two nights at the hotel.Â  Combined was responsible for paying
  for Ardisâ€™ room on both Friday and Saturday nights.[1]Â 
  Ristau stated he was aware that Ardis and one other employee of Combined were
  spending Saturday night at the hotel.Â  While Ristau did not stay at the Holiday
  Inn, he testified that he stayed at another hotel in Atlanta on Saturday night
  in preparation for a trip on Sunday to Nashville, Tennessee.Â  
The
  purpose of the sales meeting was to train employees for a new company incentive
  program.Â  Several employees, including Ardis, also received sales awards.Â 
  Combined did not dispute that Ardisâ€™
  presence in Marietta was directly related
  to and caused by Ardisâ€™ employment with
  Combined. Â Â 
Because
  the drive back to Wedgefield was approximately five hours, Ardis and Connor
  chose to spend Saturday night at the hotel and drive back the next morning.Â 
  After the meeting concluded on Saturday, Connor testified she and Ardis
  shopped, bowled, and ate supper before returning to the hotel between 11:30
  p.m. and 12:00 a.m.Â  They watched a movie in their room and fell asleep around
  1:00 a.m.Â  The couple was awakened by a fire alarm early Sunday morning and
  attempted to leave the hotel.Â  However, due to the thick smoke, Ardis was
  unable to escape and died as a result of smoke inhalation.Â  
As
  personal representative of Ardisâ€™ estate,
  Ardisâ€™ mother initiated a workersâ€™ compensation claim, requesting a lump sum
  settlement and burial expenses in accordance with South Carolina Code Sections
  42-9-140 and 42-9-290 (1976).Â  After a hearing, the Single Commissioner found
  that Ardisâ€™ decision to remain in Marietta was reasonable as Ardis â€œwould have
  been required to travel approximately five hours after a complete day of
  training.â€Â  As a result, the Single Commissioner concluded Ardis sustained a
  compensable fatal injury by accident and relied on the dual purpose doctrine to
  buttress his conclusion.Â  Consequently, he awarded Ardisâ€™ beneficiaries $2,500
  in burial expenses and a lump sum payment for the commuted value of 500 weeks
  of compensation at the rate of $396.58 per week.Â  The Commission
  unanimously affirmed the Single Commissioner.Â  On appeal, the circuit court
  affirmed the Commission.Â  This appeal follows. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review
  for decisions by the Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130,
  135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  Although we may not substitute our judgment
  for that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of
  fact, we may reverse when the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Grant
    v. Grant Textiles, 372 S.C. 196, 200-01, 641 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2007).Â  Our
  review is limited to deciding whether the Commissionâ€™s decision is
  unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.Â  Id. at 201, 641 S.E.2d at 871.Â  When the facts are not in dispute, as in the
  instant case, the question of whether or not the accident is compensable
  becomes purely a question of law.Â  Douglas v. Spartan Mills, Startex
    Div., 245 S.C. 265, 266, 140 S.E.2d 173, 173 (1965).
LAW/ANAYSIS
I. Injury by Accident
  Arising Out of and in the Course of Employment
Combined contends
  the circuit court erred in affirming the decision of the Commission because
  Ardisâ€™ death did not occur within the
  scope and course of his employment.Â  We disagree.
To
  be compensable, an injury by accident must be one â€œarising out of and in the
  course of employment.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (Supp. 2007).Â  The two parts
  of the phrase â€œarising out of and in the course of employmentâ€ are not
  synonymous.Â  Osteen v. Greenville County Sch. Dist., 333 S.C. 43, 49,
  508 S.E.2d 21, 24 (1998).Â  Also, both parts must exist simultaneously before a
  court will allow recovery.Â  Id.Â  â€œArising out ofâ€ refers to the injuryâ€™s origin and
  cause, whereas â€œin the course ofâ€ refers to the injuryâ€™s time, place,
  and circumstances.Â  Id. at 50, 508 S.E.2d at 24. Â Â 
For
  an injury to â€œarise out ofâ€ employment, the injury must be proximately caused
  by the employment.Â  Douglas, 245 S.C. at 269, 140 S.E.2d at 175.Â  An
  injury arises out of employment when there is a causal connection between the
  conditions under which the work is required to be performed and the resulting
  injury.Â  Id.Â  Further, the injury does not have to be foreseen or
  expected, but after the event, it must appear to have originated in a risk
  connected with the employment and to have come from that source as a rational
  consequence.Â  Id.Â  An injury occurs â€œin the course ofâ€ employment when
  it happens within the period of employment at a place where the employee
  reasonably may be in the performance of the employeeâ€™s duties and
  while fulfilling those duties or engaging in something incidental to those
  duties.Â  Broughton v. South of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 498, 520 S.E.2d
  634, 639 (Ct. App. 1999).
Ardisâ€™ death arose out of his employment because he was
  expected to be in Marietta the weekend of January 13-15, 2006 for a
  company-sponsored sales meeting.Â  The causal connection between Ardisâ€™ death
  and his employment is clear.Â  Combined concedes Ardis would not have been in Marietta that weekend but for the conference.Â  Ardisâ€™ presence in Marietta and ultimately
  his death at the hotel were direct consequences of attending the meeting that
  weekend.Â  
Citing
  to Brownlee v. Wetterau Food Serv., 288 S.C. 82, 339 S.E.2d 694 (Ct.
  App. 1986), Combined argues Ardisâ€™ death occurred outside the course of
  employment because Ardis died after the meeting ended, away from Combinedâ€™s
  premises, and at a time when Combined exercised no control over his activities.Â 
  In Brownlee, Wetterau sent its employee, Kenneth Brownlee, to a training
  seminar in St. Louis, Missouri.Â  Id. at 84, 339 S.E.2d at 695.Â  The
  seminar took place from 7:00 a.m. until 10:00 p.m. each day at the hotel where
  Brownlee was staying.Â  Id.Â  Around 9:00 p.m. on the Thursday evening of
  the seminar, Brownlee and three other people attending the seminar decided to
  attend a movie.Â  Id.Â  Brownlee rode as a passenger in a company-owned
  vehicle to the movies.Â  Id.Â  At approximately 2:00 a.m. on the return
  trip to the hotel, all four people were killed in a three-car collision.Â  Id.Â  This Court found that Brownleeâ€™s death was not compensable because his
  activities were not job related or employer sponsored.Â  Id. at 85, 339
  S.E.2d at 695.Â  Further, his death occurred some distance from the hotel and
  several hours after the last scheduled seminar event had concluded.Â  Id. at 84, 339 S.E.2d at 695.Â  
Brownlee bears factual similarities to the instant case,
  namely that Ardis died while attending an out-of-town seminar.Â  However, Ardisâ€™
  death occurred in a distinctly different place and manner than that of the
  employee in Brownlee.Â  At the time of Ardisâ€™ death, he was in the hotel
  where the seminar took place, sleeping in a room paid for and reserved by
  Combined.Â  See 2 Arthur Larson
  & Lex K. Larson, Larsonâ€™s Workersâ€™ Compensation Law Â§ 25.02, 25-2 (2008) (stating â€œ[a] traveling employee
  who dies as a result of a fire or asphyxiation in a hotel or motel during the
  business trip is within the coverage of the compensation acts . . . [as] there
  is no difference in principle between the employee who is housed upon the
  employerâ€™s own premises and the employee who is housed in a hotel room paid for
  by the employerâ€).Â  Moreover, Brownleeâ€™s
  decision to venture away from the hotel inevitably precipitated his death,
  whereas Ardisâ€™ death was the result of circumstances wholly outside his
  immediate control.[2]Â  While his death in the
  hotel fire may not have been expected or even foreseeable, the possibility that
  he could be injured or perish while on an out-of-town business trip is a risk
  directly connected with the nature of Ardisâ€™ employment.Â  See Stone
    v. Traylor Bros., Inc., 360 S.C. 271, 275, 600 S.E.2d 551, 552-53 (Ct. App.
  2004) (stating the injury need not be expected or even foreseeable but must
  appear to have originated in a risk connected to the employment and to have
  flowed from that source as a rational consequence). Â Â 
Combined
  maintains the business purpose of the trip ended at the conclusion of the
  seminar; therefore, Ardisâ€™ presence at the hotel on Saturday night was outside
  the scope of his employment since he was no longer in the performance of his
  duties.Â  The seminar and Ardisâ€™ official business duties may have ended earlier
  that day, but it is reasonably foreseeable and incidental to the fulfillment of
  his duties for Ardis and Connor to have spent the night in Marietta before
  making the five-hour drive back to Wedgefield.Â  See Beam v. State
    Workmensâ€™ Comp. Fund, 261 S.C. 327, 332, 200 S.E.2d 83, 86 (1973) (stating â€œan employee, to
  be entitled to compensation, need not be in the actual performance of the
  duties for which he was expressly employed in order for his injury or death to
  be in the â€˜course of employmentâ€™ [as long as] the employee is engaged in a
  pursuit or undertaking . . . which in some logical manner pertains to . . . his
  employmentâ€); see also Broughton,
  336 S.C. at 498, 520 S.E.2d at 639 (stating an employee is within the course of
  employment for purposes of coverage under the Act if injured while fulfilling
  work-related duties or engaging in something incidental to those duties). 
Ardis
  had driven five hours the preceding day, had spent almost the entire afternoon
  in a meeting solely related to his employerâ€™s business, and arguably wanted to
  return to Wedgefield on Sunday morning following a good nightâ€™s rest. Â Because
  the sun sets earlier in January, even if they left immediately after the
  conference ended, they would not arrive in Wedgefield until after dark.Â 
  Although Ardis was not engaged in the actual performance of his business
  duties, Ardisâ€™ act of sleeping in the hotel room before returning home the next
  morning is a logical action given the circumstances and is therefore incidental
  to the business trip.Â  see also Martin v. Georgia-Pacific Corp., 167 S.E.2d
  790, 793 (N.C. Ct. App. 1969) (internal citation omitted) (stating â€œtraveling
  employees, whether or not on call, usually do receive protection when the
  injury has its origin in a risk created by the necessity of sleeping and eating
  away from home. . . . [t]he hotel fire cases are the best illustration of
  thisâ€); cf. Larson & Larson, supra, Â§ 25.03[1] (stating that
  similar to injuries sustained by a traveling employee while sleeping away from
  home, injuries sustained by a traveling employee while dining have â€œbeen held
  compensable, even though the accident occurred on a Sunday evening, a day off,
  or involved an extended trip occasioned by the employeeâ€™s wish to eat at
  a particular restaurant or barâ€) (emphasis added). 
II. Substantial Deviation 
Combined
  additionally argues Ardis participated in a series of personal activities that
  constituted a substantial deviation from the course of his employment.Â 
  Combined argues Ardisâ€™ acts of going to dinner, shopping, and bowling were substantial
  deviations that rendered Ardis outside the scope of his employment at the time
  of his death.Â  We disagree.
â€œAn
  identifiable deviation from a business trip for personal reasons takes the
  employee out of the course of employment until the employee returns to the
  route of the business trip, unless the deviation is so small as to be
    disregarded as insubstantial.â€Â  Gibson v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist., 338
  S.C. 510, 522, 526 S.E.2d 725, 731 (Ct. App. 2000) (internal citation omitted)
  (emphasis in original).Â  
Even
  assuming the above-mentioned activities were identifiable deviations, Ardisâ€™ death occurred while he was sleeping at the hotel
  such that any deviation was cured or abandoned by the time of the accident.Â 
  Further, the act of sleeping, although a
  personal activity, was incidental to his employment such that his death arose
  out of his employment.Â  Sleeping is expressly included within the scope of the personal comfort doctrine.Â  The personal comfort
  doctrine states, â€œSuch acts as are necessary to the life, comfort, and
  convenience of the [employee] while at work, though strictly personal . . . and
  not acts of service, are incidental to the service, and injury sustained in the
  performance thereof is deemed to have arisen out of the employment.â€Â  Id. at 519, 526 S.E.2d at 730 (citing Osteen,
  333 S.C. at 46, 508 S.E.2d at 23).Â  This includes â€œimperative acts
  such as eating, drinking, smoking, seeking relief from discomfort, preparing to
  begin or quit work, and resting or sleeping.â€Â  Id. at 519-20, 526
  S.E.2d at 730 (emphasis added).Â  
Based on the
  circumstances, Ardisâ€™ decision to sleep at the hotel in Marietta on Saturday
  night was an act that was necessary to Ardisâ€™ â€œlife, comfort, and
  convenience.â€Â  See Larson & Larson, supra, Â§ 25.01 (2008)
  (stating â€œ[e]mployees whose work entails travel away from the employerâ€™s
  premises are held in the majority of jurisdictions to be within the course of
  their employment continuously during the trip . . . [t]hus, injuries arising
  out of the necessity of sleeping in hotels or eating in restaurants away from
  home are usually held compensableâ€).Â  Combined implicitly recognized the
  reasonableness of Ardisâ€™ decision to stay in Marietta by reserving and paying
  for Ardisâ€™ room.Â  Furthermore, we believe a fundamental premise underlying the
  personal comfort doctrine is that while certain activities undertaken by an
  employee may immediately benefit the employee in a personal sense, a benefit
  ultimately inures to the employer as well.Â  See Osteen, 333 S.C.
  at 46-47, 508 S.E.2d at 23 (stating that while an employee who engages in
  entirely personal activities may be â€œminister[ing] unto himself . . . in a
  remote sense these acts contribute to the furtherance of his workâ€).Â  Consequently, Ardisâ€™ death occurred during an activity
  that was incidental to his employment and thus was compensable under the Act.Â  
III. Dual Purpose Doctrine
Last, Combined argues the dual purpose doctrine, as
  relied upon by the Commission, does not bring Ardisâ€™ death within the course of his employment because he
  substantially deviated from the business purpose of the trip at the time of his
  death.Â  
The dual purpose
  doctrine states the following:

  [W]hen a trip serves both business and personal purposes, it is a
    personal trip if the trip would have been made in spite of the failure or
    absence of the business purpose and would have been dropped in the event of
    failure of the private purpose, though the business errand remained undone; it
    is a business trip if a trip of this kind would have been made in spite of the
    failure or absence of the private purpose, because the service to be performed
    for the employer would have caused the journey to be made by someone even if it
    had not coincided with the employeeâ€™s personal journey. 

Gibson, 338 S.C. at 520, 526 S.E.2d at 730.
Combined
  concedes Ardisâ€™ trip to Marietta was for
  a business purpose.Â  While Ardis may have engaged in some personal activities
  during the business trip, he traveled to Marietta solely for the benefit of his
  employer.Â  In the absence of the business purpose, Ardis would not have made
  the trip at all.Â  See Gibson, 338 S.C. at 521, 526 S.E.2d at 731
  (finding teacherâ€™s injury at Wal-Mart while buying school supplies as well as a
  lunch box for her child was compensable when trip served both a business and
  personal purpose but trip was made solely for benefit of school district and in
  absence of business purpose, the trip would not have occurred at all).Â  Having
  already found Ardis did not substantially deviate from this business purpose at
  the time of his death, we conclude the circuit court properly affirmed the
  Commission in finding Ardisâ€™ death occurred in the course and scope of his
  employment.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and
HUFF, J., concur. Â 


[1] Combined attempted to argue to the circuit court and
  to this Court that it was unclear as to whether Combined ever paid for Ardisâ€™
  room at the hotel due to Combinedâ€™s direct billing system.Â  In its brief,
  Combined stated under this billing system, it would pay the cost of the room up
  front and then charge the expense to the employeeâ€™s account.Â  However, because
  Combined offered sales incentives to its employees to offset the chargeback, an
  employeeâ€™s room could be paid for if the employee reached certain sales
  achievements.Â  Because the Commission found substantial evidence existed in the
  record to establish Combined paid for Ardisâ€™ room and because Combined concedes
  on appeal the facts are undisputed such that our review is limited only to
  legal errors, the Commissionâ€™s factual determination on this issue is
conclusive.
[2] In acknowledging that Brownlee was engaged in an
  activity planned by himself and other seminar participants at the time of his
  death, this Court noted that the record was devoid of evidence that Brownlee
  died while returning to the hotel from a restaurant, as eating and going to eat
  are viewed as being within the scope of employment on out-of-town business
trips.Â  Brownlee, 288 S.C. at 84-85, 339 S.E.2d at 695-96.Â  Â

title: Buice v. WMA Securities, Inc.
description: Steeley Humphrey, and WMA Securities, Inc. (collectively Appellants) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s denial of their Motion to Dismiss, or in the Alternative, to Stay and Compel Arbitration in an action filed by Respondents Jerry and Anna Buice, Brenda Sprinkle, and Haley Nicole Smith Williams (collectively Investors).   We affirm as modified.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Case No.:
          2005-CP-23-04718
        Anna M. Buice
          and Jerry W. Buice, Respondents,
        v.
        WMA Securities,
          Inc., Steeley Hubert Humphrey, Jr., Carl David Kennedy and W. Lindsey Howell, Defendants,
        Of Whom WMA Securities,
          Inc., Steeley Hubert Humphrey, Jr. and Carl David Kennedy are Appellants.
        Case No.:
          2005-CP-23-04719
        Brenda B.
          Sprinkle, Respondent,
        v.
        WMA Securities,
          Inc., Steeley Hubert Humphrey, Jr., Carl David Kennedy, and W. Lindsey
          Howell, Defendants,
        Of whom  WMA
          Securities, Inc., Steeley Hubert Humphrey, Jr. and Carl David Kennedy are Appellants.
        Case No.:
          2005-CP-23-04720
        Haley Nicole
          Smith Williams, Respondent,
        v.
        WMA Securities,
          Inc., Steeley Hubert Humphrey, Jr., Carl David Kennedy and W. Lindsay Howell, Defendants,
        Of Whom  WMA
          Securities, Inc., Steeley Hubert Humphrey, Jr. and Carl David Kennedy are Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4442
  Heard September 17, 2008 â€“ Filed October
14, 2008Â  

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
        Anthony E. Rebollo, Carmen Vaughn Ganjehsani and Charles E. Carpenter, Jr., all of Columbia, for Appellant Carl David Kennedy, and Ellis M. Johnston, II and Joel M. Bondurant, Jr., of Greenville, for Appellants WMA Securitites, Inc. and Steeley Hubert Humphrey, Jr.
        Ben C. Harrison, Max Hyde and Jeremy A. Dantin, all of Spartanburg,
          for Respondents.
      
    
  

HEARN,
  C.J.: Â Steeley Humphrey, and WMA
  Securities, Inc. (collectively Appellants) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s denial of
  their Motion to Dismiss, or in the Alternative, to Stay and Compel Arbitration
  in an action filed by Respondents Jerry and Anna Buice, Brenda Sprinkle, and
  Haley Nicole Smith Williams (collectively Investors).[1] Â We affirm as modified.
FACTS
 In early 1999,
  Investor Sprinkle met Howell, an agent/employee of WMAS, in the course of
  procuring supplemental health insurance for her elderly parents.Â  During
  several resulting conversations between the two, Howell inquired about
  assisting Sprinkle with other aspects of her financial planning.Â  Also during
  this same period, Sprinkle introduced Howell to several of her co-workers,
  including the Buices and Williams.Â  Investors allege Howell recommended
  purchasing variable universal life insurances policies (Policies) as safe and
  prudent investments through which each could earn enough profit to cover all
  future insurance premiums.Â  As a result of these conversations, and in reliance
  on Howellâ€™s advice, Investors separately purchased Policies between January of
  1999, and June of 2000.[2]Â 
  The Investorsâ€™ applications were identical,[3] and each included an Arbitration Agreement.Â  
The Arbitration
  Agreement appears under the heading â€œCLIENT PRE-DISPUTE ARBITRATIONâ€ and in
  relevant part provides:

  
    I (we)
      agree that unless unenforceable due to federal or state law, any controversy
      arising out of or related to my (our) accounts, the transactions with WMAS, its
      officers, directors, agents, registered representatives and/or employees for me
      (us), or related to this agreement or breach thereof, shall be settled by
      arbitration in accordance with the rules then in effect of the National
      Association of Securities Dealers, Inc. (NASD).Â  Such arbitration shall follow
      the procedures as set forth by a national arbitration committee of the NASD.Â  .
      . .
  

(emphasis added).Â  The
  Arbitration Agreement concludes, in pertinent part:

  
    I (we)
      understand that:
      (1)
      ARBITRATION IS FINAL AND BINDING ON THE PARTIES (I.E., YOU AND WMAS).
      (2) YOU
      AND WMAS ARE WAIVING RIGHTS TO SEEK REMEDIES IN COURT, INCLUDING THE RIGHT TO
      JURY TRIAL.
      . . .
  

Following each of
  their investments, Investors contend they discovered Appellants had materially
  misrepresented and omitted vital information regarding the Policies, upon which
  they had relied in their purchase.Â  Investors allege Appellants failed to
  disclose that the Policies were actually â€œmutual fund type account[s] â€˜wrappedâ€™
  inside [] insurance polic[ies]â€ requiring the separate purchase of life
  insurance regardless of an individualâ€™s need for ancillary life insurance.Â 
  Investors further maintain Howell failed to disclose the higher sales
  commission he stood to earn from the Policies as compared to other investment
  alternatives, or that the Policies are generally considered high-risk
  securities.Â  
Originally, Investors filed the necessary paperwork with the NASD to bring their action in
  arbitration.Â  (emphasis added).Â  However, shortly after filing, Investors
  received a return letter from the NASD stating WMASâ€™s NASD membership had been
  terminated, and Investors â€œ[could], but [are] not required to, arbitrate
  [their] claimâ€ based on NASD Code of Arbitration Procedure Rule 10301.Â  Rule
  10301[4] provides:

  
    10301. Required Submission
      (a) Any
      dispute, claim or controversy eligible for submission under the Rule 10100 Series between a customer and a member and/or associated person arising in
      connection with the business of such member or in connection with the
      activities of such associated persons shall be arbitrated under this Code, as
      provided by any duly executed and enforceable written agreement or upon the
      demand of the customer.Â  A claim involving a member in the following categories shall be ineligible for submission to arbitration under the Code unless
        the customer agrees in writing to arbitrate the claim after it has arisen:
    
      1.
        A member whose membership is terminated,suspended, canceled,
        or revoked;
        2.
        A member that has been expelled from theNASD; or
        3.
        A member that is otherwise defunct.
      
  

(emphasis added).Â  
Investors then filed
  suit in circuit court against Carl Kennedy,[5] Howell, Humphrey, and WMAS, asserting eight causes of action: (1) violation of
  South Carolinaâ€™s securities laws; (2) breach of fiduciary duty; (3) negligence;
  (4) breach of contract; (5) breach of covenant of good faith and fair dealing;
  (6) fraud; (7) breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act; and (8)
  control person liability. Â Kennedy, WMAS and Humphrey filed a Motion to Dismiss
  or in the Alternative, to Stay and Compel Arbitration. Â A hearing was held, and
  relying on Rule 10301 and a perceived ambiguity, the circuit court denied all
  the motions by written order. Â Ensuing Motions to Reconsider were also denied. Â This
  appeal followed. Â Before oral arguments to this court, Investors and Kennedy
  agreed by stipulation that Investorsâ€™ claims against him are subject to
  arbitration before the NASD, and, therefore, Kennedyâ€™s appeal was dismissed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe determination
  of whether a claim is subject to arbitration is subject to de novo review.â€Â  Wellman,
    Inc. v. Square D Co., 366 S.C. 61, 67, 620 S.E.2d 86, 89 (Ct. App. 2005).Â 
  However, a circuit courtâ€™s factual findings will not be reversed on appeal if
  any evidence reasonably supports the findings.Â  Thornton v. Trident
    Med. Ctr., L.L.C., 357 S.C. 91, 94, 592 S.E.2d 50, 51 (Ct. App. 2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. WMAS
WMAS first contends
  the agreement entered into by the parties stipulates that NASD rules â€œthen in
  effectâ€ would govern any dispute arising from the agreement, and that because
  Rule 10301 did not exist at the time the parties signed their agreement, it
  should have no applicability.Â  WMAS also contends the circuit court erred in
  refusing, assuming Rule 10301â€™s applicability, to compel arbitration, where the
  rule does not preclude arbitration, and the parties entered into an otherwise
  contractually binding arbitration agreement with respect to claims arising out
  of the contract.Â  We disagree.
The crux of the
  analysis of the arbitration agreement hinges on a determination of how the
  phrase â€œthen in effectâ€ modifies the set of NASD rules to be applied in the
  arbitration.Â  We find the phrase â€œthen in effectâ€ clearly and unambiguously
  refers to the NASD rules existing at the time the matter is sent to
  arbitration.Â  Hawkins v. Greenwood Dev. Corp., 328 S.C. 585, 592, 493
  S.E.2d 875, 878 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œThe construction of a clear and unambiguous contract is a question
  of law for the court.â€).Â  Our analysis is bolstered by
  four previous decisions of courts around the country that have had the occasion
  to interpret NASD Rule 10301â€™s effect on a terminated memberâ€™s right to still
  compel arbitration after the ruleâ€™s enaction.Â  See In re Sands Bros.
    & Co., Ltd., 206 S.W.3d 127 (Tex. App. 2006); Gailey v. World
      Marketing Alliance, 2006 WL 1716871 (N.D.Miss. 2006); Provencio v. WMA Sec., Inc., 125 Cal. App. 4th 1028 (Cal. App. 2d 2005); Elston v.
        Toma, 2004 WL 1048132 (D.Or. 2004).Â  Moreover, similar to the Elston courtâ€™s deconstruction of a comparable contractual clause, we find WMASâ€™
  inclusion of the NASD as the specified arbitration forum and applicable rules,
  limits its ability to make a colorable argument that arbitration should be enforced
  despite the clear exclusion under NASD Rule 10301 for those whose memberships
  have been terminated.Â  This is also represented in the legislative history of
  Rule 10301, where the NASD explained:

  
    NASD Dispute Resolution believes that the proposed rule change is
      consistent with the provisions of Section 15A(b)(6) of the [Securities and
      Exchange Act of 1934] which requires, among other things, that the Associationâ€™s
      rules must be designed to prevent fraudulent and manipulative acts and
      practices, to promote just and equitable principles of trade, and, in general,
      to protect investors and the public interest. Because terminated, suspended,
      barred or otherwise defunct firms have a significantly higher incidence of
      non-payment of arbitration awards than do active firms, NASD Dispute Resolution
      believes that the proposed rule change will protect investors and the general
      public by giving customers greater flexibility to seek remedies against such
      firms.
  

66 Fed.Reg.
  13362, 13364 (proposed Mar. 5, 2001).Â  As a result, we affirm the circuit
  courtâ€™s finding that Investorsâ€™ claims against WMAS should be sent to
  arbitration only at their discretion, by subsequent written request as outlined
  by Rule 10301.
II. HumphreyÂ  
In
  addition, all parties to this appeal agree that WMAS and Humphreyâ€™s interests
  are identical.Â  Nevertheless, the circuit courtâ€™s order on appeal specifically
  delineates the two parties separately, and applies differing logic and legal
  analysis to uphold its finding that neither party should be able to compel arbitration.Â 
  The basis upon which the circuit court denied Humphreyâ€™s Motion to Compel
  Arbitration was that the contract was ambiguous.Â  We find this was error.
â€œIt is
  a question of law for the court whether the language of a
  contract is ambiguous.â€ Â S.C. Depâ€™t of Natural Res. v. Town of McClellanville, 345 S.C. 617, 623, 550 S.E.2d 299, 302-03 (2001). Â Because an arbitration clause is a contractual term,
  general rules of contract interpretation apply where the court must determine
  the clauseâ€™s applicability. Â Towles v. United Healthcare Corp., 338 S.C.
  29, 37, 524 S.E.2d 839, 844 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  In
  determining as a matter of law whether a
  contract is ambiguous, the court must consider the contract as a whole, rather than deciding whether phrases in isolation could be
  interpreted in various ways: Â â€œ[O]ne may not, by pointing out a single sentence
  or clause, create an ambiguity.â€ Â Yarborough v. Phoenix Mut. Life Ins. Co., 266 S.C. 584, 592, 225 S.E.2d 344, 348 (1976). Â â€œWhether a contract is ambiguous is to be
  determined from the entire contract and not from isolated
  portions of the contract.â€Â  Farr v. Duke Power Co.,
  265 S.C. 356, 362, 218 S.E.2d 431, 433 (1975).Â  Further, in determining
  the intent of the contracting parties, the court should construe the contract
  as a whole, and read together different provisions dealing with the same
  subject matter. Skull Creek Club Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. Cook & Book, Inc.,
  313 S.C. 283, 286, 437 S.E.2d 163, 165 (Ct. App. 1993).
In finding the
  arbitration agreement ambiguous, the circuit court held:

  
    The
      first paragraph of the agreement references â€œWMAS, its officers, directors,
      agents, registered representatives and/or employee.â€ . . . The [] paragraph
      [immediately following] states, in pertinent part:Â  I (we) understand that:Â 
      (1) ARBITRATION IS FINAL AND BINDING ON THE PARTIES (i.e., YOU AND WMAS). . . .
      This Court finds that this second paragraph is set forth with greater emphasis
      than the first and is inconsistent with the preceding paragraph as to who is to
      be controlled by the arbitration agreement.
  

We find there is no
  inconsistency or ambiguity between the clauses.Â  Even acknowledging a
  difference, the most logical explanation is that the language of the first
  paragraph actually creates the agreement to arbitrate, and the second paragraph
  merely summarizes that agreement.
Moreover, assuming
  without deciding that the two clauses are incompatible, the first clause should
  be given greater weight.Â  Our Supreme Court has held that where â€œthere are two
  incompatible . . . clauses [in a contract] the first will prevail over the
  latter.â€ Phipps v. Hardwick, 273 S.C. 17, 24, 253 S.E.2d 506, 510
  (1979).Â  Further, where two clauses are incompatible, â€œthe [clause] which
  essentially requires something to be done to effect the general purpose of the
  contract is entitled to greater consideration than the other.â€ 17A Am. Jur. 2d Contracts Â§ 384 (2008).Â  Here, the first paragraph of the Arbitration Agreement defines
  how an account holder would handle a dispute, which is an operative, rather
  than descriptive, clause.Â  The second paragraph merely describes or summarizes
  the first.Â  Under this view, the first paragraph, with its reference to WMASâ€™s
  officers, directors, agents, registered representatives, and employees, would
  control.
Even
  though we disagree with the circuit courtâ€™s finding that the provision is
  ambiguous, we nevertheless affirm its decision to deny Humphreyâ€™s Motion to
  Compel Arbitration.Â  At this stage of litigation, we are willing to accept the
  partiesâ€™ determination of their own rights, and both Humphrey and WMAS have
  taken the position before the circuit court and this court that their interests
  are indistinguishable. Â Accordingly, our finding above on Rule 10301 mandates
  affirmance of the circuit courtâ€™s denial of Humphreyâ€™s Motion to Compel.Â  The
  order of the circuit court is Â 
AFFIRMED AS
  MODIFIED.
PIEPER, J., and CURETON,
  A.J., concur.Â 


[1] Williams is not represented by counsel; however, she
has agreed to be bound by the courtâ€™s disposition of the case.Â  
[2] Investorsâ€™ complaints indicate the Buices invested
$106,764.24, Sprinkle invested $95,828.00, and Williams invested $15,000.
[3] There are discrepancies between when Investors claim
  to have invested, and when documents submitted to the court indicate investments
  were made.Â  The New Account Applications included in the record indicate Williams
  signed on April 14, 1999; the Buices signed agreements on December 6 and 16,
1999; and Sprinkle signed an agreement on January 6, 2000.Â  
[4] NASD Rule 10301 was adopted on June, 11 2001.Â  
[5] Kennedy was also an agent/employee of WMAS and was
Howellâ€™s immediate supervisor.

title: South Carolina Department of Social Services v. Scott K.
description: This appeal arises from a family court order granting the South Carolina Department of Social Serviceâ€™s request to order Nedra K. (Mother) and Scott K. (Father) to comply with a Treatment Plan.  We reverse.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        South Carolina
          Department of Social Services, Respondent,
        v.
        Scott K. and
          Nedra K., Appellants.
      
    
  

In the interests of A.K. and C.K., minor
  children under the age of 18.

Appeal From Aiken County
Dale M. Gable, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 4443 
  Heard September 17, 2008 â€“ Filed October
14, 2008Â Â  

REVERSED


  
    
      
        LeLand M. Malchow, of Augusta, Georgia, for Appellant Nedra K.
        John A. Donsbach, of Martinez, Georgia, for Appellant Scott K.
        Dennis M. Gmerek, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN,
  C.J.: This appeal arises from a
  family court order granting the South Carolina Department of Social Serviceâ€™s request
  to order Nedra K. (Mother) and Scott K. (Father) to comply with a Treatment
  Plan.Â  We reverse. 
FACTS
On October 20, 2006, the Aiken County Department of Social Services
  (DSS) received a call about Mother and
  Fatherâ€™s home, reporting, â€œthere are bags of trash with maggots in them
  throughout the house . . . there is dog feces and dog urine on floors . . .
  there was the smell of marijuana in the home and marijuana smoke was seen.â€Â  Ten days later, sheriffâ€™s deputy Ken
  Blackwell accompanied DSS caseworkers Kendra Upton-Williams and Evelyn Perry on
  an unannounced visit to the home.Â  
When
  Blackwell entered the home, he observed â€œseveral bags of trash in the kitchen
  and dirty dishes in the sink.Â  The living room . . . was really cluttered with
  a lot of books and stuff stacked around.â€Â  Upton-Williams recorded her impression
  of the familyâ€™s home in a report:

  [The
    home was] cluttered with bags of trash and toys, trash thrown about the home,
    stains on the carpet, the staircase is lined with debris, the front door is
    barricaded with debris and a small shelf, the utility/storage room is filled
    with boxes of unknown items that ha[ve] been there since the couple moved into
    the home Â . . . .Â  The bottom of the floors in [the childrenâ€™s] room[s] cannot
    be seen in full.

Furthermore, Upton-Williams
  testified she discussed the condition of their home with Mother and Father; Mother
  said she â€œbecomes overwhelmed and depressed when it is time to clean her home,â€
  and Father said he tried to develop a reward system to encourage the children
  to clean their rooms.Â  On cross-examination, Upton-Williams admitted she found nothing
  in the familyâ€™s home consistent with the allegations reported to DSS â€” no dog
  feces, no urine, no maggots, and no marijuana. Â 
Motherâ€™s
  testimony regarding the condition of her home that day provides a different perspective:

  We were
    trying to get our house situated and the basement stuff done.Â  . . .Â  Our
    living room at the time had a bookcase in it to where we could get the stuff from
    [childâ€™s] room picked up and books put on shelves.Â  . . .Â  [T]he stuff outside[,]
    we were getting ready to take to Goodwill to make room in our house because we
    had no storage.Â  

Father testified and
  explained the children were spending the week at their grandparentsâ€™ home,
  while he and Mother were â€œcleaning the house and going through . . . boxes,
  rearranging things, painting . . . rooms, [and] doing a whole bunch of things
  with the house.â€Â  
At the conclusion of their visit, Upton-Williams and Perry determined
  the physical condition of the home placed Mother and Fatherâ€™s children at
  â€œserious risk of harm.â€ Â DSS asked Mother
  and Father to voluntarily
  comply with a â€œSafety Planâ€ it developed.Â  The Plan required the children to
  remain with their grandparents, who would serve â€œas protectorsâ€ of their grandchildren
  and stated DSS would give Mother and Father three days to discard all trash,
  clean the home, make the beds with clean linens, and obtain drug screens.Â  Mother testified she and Father initially had refused
  to sign the Plan, but they capitulated after DSS told them if they refused:
  â€œ[O]ur kids would be taken away, and the officer would escort us out of the
  room, and we would be arrested.â€ Â 
Upton-Williams returned to the familyâ€™s home two days later.Â  She
  testified it now was clean and acceptable, and DSS allowed the children to
  return home.Â  The following day, she
  reviewed the results of Motherâ€™s and Fatherâ€™s drug tests, which were negative.Â  Upton-Williams testified she told
  Mother and Father the Plan would remain in effect, and DSS would â€œbe coming
  back to the home to make unannounced visits,â€ until DSS made a â€œcase decision.â€
  Â 
Upton-Williams prepared a Determination Fact Sheet to â€œlet the
  family know [the] case [was] indicatedâ€ for physical neglect of the children based
  on the condition of the home.Â  Upton-Williams noted on the Fact Sheet: 

  [Father]
    does not see anything wrong with the condition of his home and feels that his
    case should be unfounded as none of the allegations were true.Â  Although the
    home had been cleaned by 11/01/06, [Father] would no longer allow DSS back into
    his home.Â  [Father] feels that his rights have been violated by DSS and the
    Aiken County Sheriffâ€™s Office.Â Â Â  

Mother
  testified regarding the disruptive impact of the DSS investigation on her
  childrenâ€™s lives.Â  She stated the children had been making Aâ€™s and Bâ€™s before DSS
  started its investigation; however, their grades began to drop because, â€œDSS
  was visiting [the children] at school and it was embarrassing to them.Â  They
  were waking up at various times of the night[,] afraid DSS was going to take
  them away.â€Â  
DSS concluded its investigation on November 20, 2006, and it classified
  the reported allegations as â€œindicated for physical neglect due to the
  condition of the home of the parents.â€Â  Thereafter, DSS developed an â€œIn-Home
  Treatment Plan,â€ and required Mother and Father to comply with it for six months.Â 
  The Plan instructed Mother and Father to: (1) keep the home clutter-free and
  pest-free; (2) wipe down the walls; (3) remove clothing from floors; (4) clean
  and maintain all rooms in the house; (5) dispose of plastic bottles, old shoes,
  and other items in the front yard; and (6) put clean linens on the beds.Â  DSS stated
  it would monitor compliance through unannounced visits, photographs, and review
  of the childrenâ€™s school records.Â  Mother and Father refused to sign the Plan
  and notified DSS they wanted to appeal its case determination.Â  In March 2007,
  DSS brought an action alleging Mother and Fatherâ€™s children were physically
  neglected, they had failed to follow the treatment plan, and the â€œchildren cannot
  be protected adequately at this time from further harm without the intervention
  of [DSS] and court-ordered services.â€[1] Â 
On
  May 24, 2007, the family court conducted an intervention hearing. Â Guardian ad
  litem (GAL) Nona Mauzy testified she had visited the familyâ€™s home on April 7
  and May 20, 2007.Â  Mauzy stated the home was indeed cluttered; however, she
  observed no signs the children were neglected:

  I
    thought that they had a good family working, just the way they got along
    together as a group. . . .Â  I didnâ€™t see any dissension or uneasiness or fear
    of any kind. . . .Â  [T]he house is cluttered, very cluttered, there is no doubt
    about that. . . .Â  I didnâ€™t feel that it was contaminated or unsanitary. . . .Â 
    It would be unsafe for me to walk through a lot of clutter on the floor because
    I am elderly and not as steady on my feet. . . .Â  I donâ€™t think there is a
    potential risk of harm right now.Â  I really donâ€™t.Â  

Furthermore, Mauzy
  interviewed Mother and Father, the children, and their grandparents and teachers
  before writing her report, which stated: 

  [Mother
    and Father] were cordial, polite and showed me through their home.Â  It was
    cluttered but not dirty.Â  The computer in the living room sits on a table and
    papers were piled all around it.Â  There are makeshift shelves in the dining
    room across one wall containing groceries and some cleaning supplies.Â  The
    kitchen is small and this looks like overflow from too few cabinets.Â  I did not
    feel that the home was unsanitary. . . .Â  The girls were clean and looked
    healthy.Â  They seemed very bright and active.

The childrenâ€™s grandfather
  told Mauzy, â€œDSS is overstepping [its] authority and that he would gladly
  testify that they are good parents but clutter did not bother either of them.â€Â 
  Mauzy testified she returned to the home a month later and found, â€œ[t]he parents
  were busy replacing the makeshift shelves in the dining room with a nice, big
  stainless steel shelving unit.â€Â  She concluded:

  Based
    on my observations I feel [the children] are normal and well-adjusted for their
    ages.Â  Both are friendly and outgoing and appear to have a normal, loving
    relationship with their Mother and Father.Â  Their teachers state that they are
    doing well and have seen no signs of neglect.Â  I feel that a referral for some
    Homemaker services could help [Mother and Father] become more organized.Â 
    [Father] should obtain employment so as to support his family.

During
  the intervention hearing, Motherâ€™s counsel asked Mauzy why her written report
  recommended affirming the DSS finding that the children were at â€œa substantial
  risk of physical neglect.â€ Â Mauzy replied, â€œ[w]ell, that confuses me even.â€Â 
  She added the GALâ€™s office â€œhelp[s] me with phrases and terms, since I donâ€™t
  have the jargon. Â I am strictly a volunteer.â€Â  Finally, when asked if the
  children were at substantial risk of physical neglect, Mauzy responded: â€œChange
  that word to â€˜possible.â€™â€Â  
Following
  the hearing, the family court determined: (1) the allegations of DSS against
  Mother and Father were supported by a preponderance of the evidence; (2) the
  children are neglected due to the poor condition of their home; (3) the
  children cannot be protected from further harm without the intervention of DSS;
  and (4) the DSS Treatment Plan will alleviate the â€œdanger to these children and
  aid [Mother and Father].â€Â  Thereafter, the family court ordered Mother and
  Father to comply with the Treatment Plan.Â  Mother and Fatherâ€™s appeal followed.
STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
â€œIn
  appeals from family court, the appellate court has the authority to find the
  facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  S.C.
    Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Meek, 352 S.C. 523, 528, 575 S.E.2d 846, 848 (Ct.
  App. 2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
First,
  Mother and Father argue DSS improperly classified the allegations concerning
  the condition of their home as, â€œindicated for physical neglect due to the
  condition of the home.â€Â  Furthermore, Mother and Father contend the family
  court erred in finding a preponderance of the evidence supported the DSS
  indication and in finding the children could not be protected from future harm
  without intervention. Â As a consequence of these erroneous findings, Mother and
  Father assert the family court erred in ordering them to comply with the Treatment
  Plan.Â  We agree.Â  
A. Investigating
  Reports of Alleged Abuse and Neglect
â€œAny
  intervention by the State into family life on behalf of children must be guided
  by law, by strong philosophical underpinnings, and by sound professional
  standards for practice.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-480 (Supp. 2007).[2]Â 
  Furthermore, the statutory scheme for child protection is guided by the
  principle that, â€œ[p]arents have the primary responsibility for and are the
  primary resource for their children.â€Â  Â§ 20-7-480(A)(1).
South Carolina law states child abuse, neglect, or
  harm occurs when a person responsible for the childâ€™s welfare â€œfails to supply
  the child with adequate food, clothing, shelter, or education . . . and the
  failure to do so has caused or presents a substantial risk of causing physical
  or mental injury.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-490(2)(c) (Supp. 2007).Â  The statute provides
  clear guidelines to DSS for investigating reports of suspected child abuse or
  neglect.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-650 (Supp. 2007).Â  Within twenty-four hours of
  receiving a report of suspected child abuse or neglect, DSS must begin a
  thorough investigation. Â Â§ 20-7-650(C).Â  Furthermore, within sixty days, DSS
  must classify the report as either â€œunfoundedâ€ or â€œindicated.â€[3] Â Â§ 20-7-650(F).Â  â€œ[I]t is presumed that all reports are unfounded unless [DSS]
  determines otherwise.â€Â  Â§ 20-7-490(10).Â  â€œJust as
  SCDSS has the responsibility under the statutory scheme to bring meritorious
  allegations of child abuse and neglect before the family court, it also has the
  responsibility and duty to seek dismissal of those petitions subsequently
  determined by their investigation to be without merit.â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc.
    Servs. v. Pritcher, 329 S.C. 242, 247, 495 S.E.2d 242, 244 (Ct. App.
  1997).Â  The goal of this statutory scheme â€œis to protect children while
  avoiding intervention into the familyâ€™s life if at all possible.â€Â  Id. at 248, 495 S.E.2d at 245.Â  
After
  DSS classifies a report as indicated, it may petition the family court for
  authority to intervene and provide protective services if it makes the
  two-pronged determination: (1) by a preponderance of evidence, the child is an abused
  or neglected child, and (2) the child cannot be protected from harm without
  intervention.Â  Â§ 20-7-738(A) (Supp. 2007).Â  In this case, DSS found a cluttered
  home, but its investigation failed to substantiate any of the reported allegations.
  Â Moreover, there was no evidence that Mother and Fatherâ€™s children had been
  harmed or were at risk of future harm.Â  To the contrary, all the evidence
  showed the children to be healthy and well nurtured; in the words of the GAL,
  â€œthey had a good family.â€Â  Accordingly, we find DSS erred in classifying the reported
  allegations.Â  Moreover, DSS compounded its error by equating Mother and
  Fatherâ€™s marginal housekeeping skills with the neglect of their children and in
  finding the children cannot be protected from further harm without
  intervention.
B. Family Court Intervention
The family
  court can order intervention and protective services only after it finds the
  allegations of the DSS petition requesting intervention are supported by a
  preponderance of the evidence, the child is abused or neglected as defined in
  section 20-7-490, and the child cannot be protected from further harm without
  intervention.Â  Â§ 20-7-738(D). Â Because a preponderance of the evidence did not
  support the allegations in the DSS petition, the family court erred in ordering
  intervention. Â Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s intervention order is
REVERSED. 
HUFF, J., and KONDUROS, J., concur.


[1] The
  following month, DSS amended its Treatment Plan to additionally require: (1)
  parenting classes; (2) Father to obtain a mental health evaluation; and (3)
  Mother to obtain depression screening. Â Noting their appeal was pending, Mother
  and Father refused to sign the amended Plan.Â  
[2] The General Assembly amended the Code of Laws of
  South Carolina, effective June 16, 2008, to add Title 63, the South Carolina
  Childrenâ€™s Code, and to transfer all provisions of Title 20, Chapter 7 to Title
  63. Â See Act No. 361, 2008 S.C. Acts 3623 (stating â€œthe transfer and
  reorganization of the code provisions in this act are technical . . . and are
  not intended to be substantiveâ€). Â Because Title 63 has not yet been bound, all
citations to the statute refer to Title 20.
[3] An unfounded report is one â€œfor which there is not a
  preponderance of evidence to believe that the child is abused or neglected.â€Â Â§ 20-7-490(10).Â  On the other
  hand, an indicated report is â€œsupported by facts which warrant a finding by a
  preponderance of evidence that abuse or neglect is more likely than not to have
  occurred.â€Â  Â§ 20-7-490(11).Â  A preponderance of evidence means â€œevidence which,
  when fairly considered, is more convincing as to its truth than the evidence in
  opposition.â€Â  Â§ 20-7-490(13).Â

title: Enos v. Doe
description: In this civil action initiated pursuant to the John Doe statute, should S.C. Code of Laws Â§ 38-77-170 be inapplicable to the facts of this case even though an affidavit was not filed?  Additionally, does the record include sufficient circumstantial evidence to create a jury issue in regard to negligence of the Respondent?
