font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Onrae Williams, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
  Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge

Opinion No.Â  4447
  Heard September 18, 2008 â€“ Filed October
22, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Mark A. Peper, of Charleston, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
          Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor
          Scarlett Wilson, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HUFF,
  J.:Â  Onrae Williams was convicted of distribution of crack
  cocaine and distribution of crack cocaine within proximity of a school.Â  Based
  upon two prior â€œseriousâ€ convictions, the trial court sentenced Williams to
  life imprisonment without the possibility of parole on both charges.Â  On
  appeal, Williams asserts error in (1) the trial courtâ€™s refusal to allow him to
  impeach the testimony of the confidential informant with evidence of several
  former convictions that were older than ten years and (2) the trial courtâ€™s
  sentencing of him to life without parole (LWOP) in violation of his
  constitutional protection from cruel and unusual punishment.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
This case involves a controlled buy set up by the City of
  Charleston Police Department using a confidential informant (CI).Â  On August
  10, 2004, officers met with the CI, searched him to insure he had no contraband
  on his person, provided him with money, and equipped him with a button camera
  capable of capturing video.Â  Because there had been numerous complaints about
  drug activity near Harmon Park, the CI was taken close to that area with a
  bicycle, which the CI then used to ride into the area.Â  Following along with
  the videotape of the incident admitted into evidence, Officer Womack indicated
  where the CI came in contact with someone, and ultimately completed a drug
  transaction approximately one hundred yards away from Burke High School.Â  Officer Womack testified he maintained a constant visual on the CI during the
  entire process, as well as a constant audio transmission.Â  When the informant
  was searched before being let out to make the buy, he had no drugs on him.Â 
  When he returned, the CI had crack cocaine in his hand.
Officer Hurteau, who was present with Officer Womack at the
  controlled buy, also testified as the video of the incident was played to the
  jury.Â  He testified the CI was not working off charges, but was a paid
  informant.Â  Officer Hurteau pointed out on the video an individual on a fence
  who was talking on a cell phone and yelled out â€œOnrae,â€ and that one could then
  observe Williams walking up from the fence area.Â  He then noted where the CI
  hands Williams money.Â  Williams is off the camera for a moment and then
  reappears, approaching the CI, at which point Williams is referred to as â€œOn.â€Â 
  Williams is seen holding something in his hand, which he places in the CIâ€™s
  hand, and then walks away.Â  When the CI returned to Officer Hurteauâ€™s location,
  he handed him two, off-white rock-like substances.Â  Officer Jenkins, who was
  also present in the area, testified he was on perimeter duty during the
  controlled buy and he observed Williams with another man near the fence as the
  CI approached the area.Â  After reviewing the video of the incident, Officers
  Hurteau and Womack, as well as Officer Jenkins, â€œall immediately without
  hesitation recognized him and said that was Onrae Williams.â€
The CI also testified to the events of that day.Â  As with Officers
  Womack and Hurteau, he followed along with the videotape of the event,
  identifying Onrae Williams on the tape and noting the completion of the
  transaction where Williams handed him drugs in exchange for money. Â He
  testified that after Williams handed him the drugs, he got back on the bicycle
  and rode back to the police officers and gave them the drugs.Â  The CI confirmed
  that the officers searched him before the transaction, as well as upon his
  return.Â  Subsequent analysis of the item showed it to be .3 grams of crack
  cocaine.
At the start of the case, Williams made an in limine motion
  seeking to admit evidence of several prior convictions of the CI that were
  greater than ten years old.Â  Specifically, Williams sought to introduce
  evidence of the CIâ€™s 1988 conviction for armed robbery, for which he was
  released from prison on August 1, 1996, as well as several forgeries and a
  larceny that occurred around 1981 and 1982.Â  Williams argued the CIâ€™s
  credibility was key to the trial as the video was not completely clear, and
  that under Rule 609(b), SCRE, the jury should have this information in the
  interest of justice.Â  Williams also noted the CI had a 2002 conviction for
  receiving stolen goods, showing the CI has continued to break the law.Â 
  Finally, Williams maintained that the matter had been pending for about a year,
  and had the State tried the case within the first six months, the armed robbery
  conviction would have fallen within the ten year limit under the rule.Â  He
  argued it was the Stateâ€™s delay in bringing the case that caused the ten-year
  period to expire between the time of his arrest and the trial, as his arrest
  occurred in January 2005, a time within the ten-year period.Â  Williams
  acknowledged, however, that he had not made a motion for a speedy trial.
The trial court noted Williams would be able to challenge the CIâ€™s
  credibility with the prior conviction for receiving stolen goods.Â  It found no
  reason under the facts of this case to extend the time limit for the other
  convictions beyond the cut-off date under the rule, but stated it would rule on
  the matter after Williams proffered the evidence.
During the CIâ€™s direct examination, he admitted to having a 2002
  conviction for receiving stolen goods.Â  During the CIâ€™s cross-examination,
  counsel questioned why the CI would become a confidential informant.Â  The CI
  stated it was â€œ[t]o try to keep â€˜em from hurting people,â€ and that it was not
  always about the money he received.Â  Counsel then asked the CI about his
  conviction for receiving stolen goods and asked whether that did not hurt
  people as well.Â  Counsel continued with this line of questioning, asking how
  long the CI had been working as a confidential informant at which point the
  following colloquy occurred:

  [Counsel]:Â  But it had nothing to do with the money?
  [CI]:Â  No, it ainâ€™t about the money.Â  I had money, you know.Â  It
    was about the drug deals.Â  I figure itâ€™s about time to make a change now.Â  Iâ€™ve
    done spent half of my life in the penitentiary.
  [Counsel]:Â  Youâ€™ve spent half your life in prison?
  [CI]:Â  Yeah.
  [Counsel]:Â  And now youâ€™ve turned your life around?
  [CI]:Â  Trying to.
  [Counsel]:Â  It was time to make a change?
  [CI]:Â  It was time to make a change, for sure.
  [Counsel]:Â  Youâ€™re an honest man now?
  [CI]:Â  I ainâ€™t going to say honest because I trip up sometimes.

Thereafter, defense counsel asserted the CI opened the door to
  testimony concerning his older prior convictions when he stated he had spent
  half of his life in the penitentiary.Â  The court noted Williams had already
  received a benefit by that answer to the question, and still found no
  exceptional circumstances in light of the CIâ€™s testimony that would warrant
  allowing convictions outside the time limit, but allowed counsel to proffer the
  evidence.Â  Outside the juryâ€™s hearing, the CI admitted he had a 1988 conviction
  for armed robbery for which he served time and was released in August 1996.Â  He
  further acknowledged a 1982 larceny conviction resulting in a two-year
  sentence, suspended to six months, as well as some forgeries and a
  housebreaking conviction in 1982 for which he received a ten-year sentence.Â 
  The solicitor objected to introduction of the prior convictions, arguing it was
  not probative, it was unduly prejudicial, and defense counsel had already
  accomplished his goals through the testimony he elicited from the CI.Â  The
  trial court ruled the circumstances did not warrant allowing the older prior
  convictions, and the issue was resolved by the CIâ€™s answers on
  cross-examination.Â  
The
  jury found Williams guilty of the distribution and proximity charges.Â  The
  solicitor stated Williams had several previous convictions, including a 2000
  possession with intent to distribute cocaine and a proximity charge, as well as
  a possession of crack charge, and in 2003 had distribution of marijuana,
  distribution of cocaine, proximity, and possession of cocaine charges.Â  The
  court noted Williams had at least two previous serious offenses such that this
  offense would qualify as a third.Â  Defense counsel agreed and further stated he
  did not believe the court had â€œmuch discretionâ€ as far as sentencing, but
  placed an objection on the record to a life without parole sentence.Â  Counsel
  maintained such a sentence would constitute cruel and unusual punishment as
  this was a drug crime and not a violent crime.Â  He argued, in this case, life
  without parole would be excessive, unduly severe, and would violate the due
  process clause.Â  The court sentenced Williams to life without parole on both
  offenses.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
A. Prior remote convictions
Williams
  first contends the trial court erred by refusing to allow evidence of the CIâ€™s
  former convictions for armed robbery, larceny, forgery and housebreaking.Â  He
  argues the trial court erred in failing to admit this evidence because (1) the
  CI opened the door to the evidence by stating he spent half his life in prison
  and (2) the court failed to apply the proper balancing test in ruling Williams
  could not challenge the CIâ€™s credibility pursuant to Rule 609, SCRE.Â  We find
  no reversible error.
The admission
  or exclusion of evidence falls within the sound discretion of the trial court
  and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of that discretion.Â  State
    v. Morris, 376 S.C. 189, 205, 656 S.E.2d 359, 368 (2008).Â  As well, the
  scope of cross-examination is within the discretion of the trial court, and the
  courtâ€™s decision will not be reversed on appeal absent a showing of prejudice.Â  State v. Colf, 337 S.C. 622, 625, 525 S.E.2d 246, 247-48 (2000).Â 
  Further, any error in the trial courtâ€™s failure to conduct the proper balancing
  test in determining whether remote convictions are admissible may be harmless.Â  State v. Johnson, 363 S.C. 53, 60, 609 S.E.2d 520, 524 (2005). Â To
  constitute error, the trial courtâ€™s ruling to admit or exclude evidence must
  affect a substantial right.Â  Id.; Rule 103(a), SCRE.Â Â  Error is considered
  harmless where it could not reasonably have affected the outcome of the trial.Â  State v. Bryant, 369 S.C. 511, 518, 633 S.E.2d 152, 156 (2006).Â  â€œGenerally,
  appellate courts will not set aside convictions due to insubstantial errors not
  affecting the result.Â  Thus, an insubstantial error not affecting the result of
  the trial is harmless where a defendantâ€™s guilt has been conclusively proven by
  competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion can be reached.â€Â  Id. Â (citations omitted). Â In determining whether error is harmless, the
  circumstances of each individual case are to be considered.Â  Id.; Johnson,
  363 S.C. at 60, 609 S.E.2d at 524.
Even
  assuming arguendo that the trial court failed to apply the proper balancing
  test or that the court erred in refusing to admit the evidence based on the
  CIâ€™s opening door, we find any such error would be harmless.Â  Here, contrary to
  Williamsâ€™ assertion, the CI was not the only witness for the State who could
  identify him and place him at the scene.Â  Officer Hurteau testified, while following the videotape, that you
  could hear an individual at the scene yelling out the name â€œOnrae,â€ and at a
  later point on the tape noted Williams is referred to as â€œOn.â€Â Â  He further
  indicated you could observe Williams on the videotape and also could see
  Williams holding a small substance in his hand, which he places in the CIâ€™s
  hand.Â  Officer Jenkins, who was on perimeter duty during the controlled buy,
  testified he observed Williams with another man near the fence as the CI
  approached the area.Â  Officer Womack testified he maintained a constant visual
  on the CI during the entire process, and that the CI was searched before being
  let out to make the buy and had no drugs on him, but had crack cocaine in his
  hand when he returned.Â  Finally, after reviewing the video of the incident,
  Officer Hurteau testified he and Officer Womack, as well as Officer Jenkins,
  all immediately and without hesitation recognized Onrae Williams as the
  individual who sold the drugs to the CI.[1]Â  
Further, the CI was already impeached with admission of his
  conviction of receiving stolen goods, a crime the CI acknowledged before the
  jury was a crime of dishonesty.Â  The CIâ€™s credibility was clearly called into
  question by this, along with his admission he had spent half of his life in the
  penitentiary and his refusal to characterize himself as honest.Â  See State
    v. Cooper, 312 S.C. 90, 92, 439 S.E.2d 276, 277 (1994) (holding any error in
  excluding evidence of witnessâ€™ prior bad acts harmless, where witness was
  thoroughly impeached by admission of numerous previous convictions and
  acknowledgment his testimony was given for favorable treatment on pending
  charges), overruled in part on other grounds by Franklin v. Catoe,
  346 S.C. 563, 575, 552 S.E.2d 718, 725 (2001); State v. Tillman, 304
  S.C. 512, 520, 405 S.E.2d 607, 612 (Ct. App. 1991) (finding, where witness was
  thoroughly impeached by admission of numerous prior convictions and his
  acknowledgment that he was testifying under an agreement to receive favorable
  treatment on some outstanding charges, any error in excluding evidence of a
  particular crime he might have committed was harmless).Â  
Aside from the CIâ€™s testimony, there is evidence of record placing
  Williams at the scene and identifying him as the individual engaged in the drug
  transaction with the CI.Â  There is also evidence showing the CI, while under
  constant visual, returned with drugs that he did not have when he left the
  officers.Â  Given all this evidence, along with the fact that the CI was
  thoroughly impeached by evidence of his crime of dishonesty and his admissions
  he had spent half of his life in jail and that he would not characterize
  himself as honest, we find exclusion of
  the CIâ€™s remote convictions could not reasonably have affected the result of
  the trial.Â  Considering the circumstances of this case, we therefore conclude
  any possible error in the exclusion of the evidence is harmless.
B.Â  LWOP sentence
Williams
  next contends the trial court erred in sentencing him to life in prison without
  parole in violation of his constitutional protection from cruel and unusual
  punishment.Â  He asserts, under State v. Pittman, 373 S.C. 527, 647
  S.E.2d 144 (2007), cert. denied, 128 S.Ct. 1872 (2008), the two
  principles to consider in determining whether a punishment is cruel and unusual
  are (1) the evolving standards of decency that mark the progress of a maturing
  society and (2) the proportionality between the punishment and the offense.Â  He
  argues an LWOP sentence for distribution of less than half a gram of a
  controlled substance is inconsistent with evolving standards of contemporary
  values.Â  Williams further asserts an LWOP sentence under the recidivist statute
  is grossly disproportionate to the punishment deserved for distribution of less
  than half a gram of cocaine, especially where the first conviction used to
  qualify him for LWOP was committed as a juvenile.Â  We disagree.
Section
  17-25-45(B) of the South Carolina Code requires that â€œupon a conviction for a
  serious offense . . . a person must be sentenced to a term of imprisonment for
  life without the possibility of parole if that person has two or more prior
  convictions for: Â (1) a serious offense.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45(B) (2003).
The
  Eighth Amendment to the United States Constitution provides, â€œExcessive bail
  shall not be required, nor excessive fines imposed, nor cruel and unusual
  punishments inflicted.â€Â  U.S. Const. amend. XIII.Â  The cruel and unusual
  punishment clause requires that the duration of a sentence not be grossly disproportionate
  with the severity of the crime.Â  State v. McKnight, 352 S.C. 635, 652,
  576 S.E.2d 168, 177 (2003).Â  
Most
  recently, our courts have recognized that â€œwhat constitutes cruel and unusual
  punishment, and thus, what violates the Eighth Amendment, is determined by â€˜evolving
  standards of decency that mark the progress of a maturing society.â€™â€ Â State
    v. Pittman, 373 S.C. 527, 562, 647 S.E.2d 144, 162 (2007), cert. denied,
  128 S.Ct. 1872 (2008) (quoting State v. Standard, 351 S.C. 199, 204, 569
  S.E.2d 325, 328 (2002)). Â In implementing this test, the court looks to
  objective evidence of how our society views a particular punishment today. Â State
    v. Wilson, 306 S.C. 498, 509-10, 413 S.E.2d 19, 26 (1992).Â  Legislation
  enacted by the countryâ€™s legislatures is the â€œclearest and most reliable
  objective evidence of contemporary values.â€Â  Pittman, 373 S.C. at 563,
  647 S.E.2d at 162.Â  â€œ[T]he Constitution requires the courtâ€™s own judgment to be
  brought to bear on the issue by â€˜asking whether there is reason to disagree
  with the judgment reached by the citizenry and its legislators.â€™â€Â  Id. at 563, 647 S.E.2d at 163 (quoting Atkins v. Virginia, 536 U.S. 304, 313 (2002)).Â  It is not the burden of the state to establish a national consensus
  approving what their citizens have voted to do; rather, it is the heavy burden
  of the defendant to establish a national consensus against it. Â Wilson, 306 S.C. at 510, 413 S.E.2d at 26.Â  
Additionally,
  the â€œâ€˜proportionalityâ€™ bedrock of Eighth Amendment jurisprudenceâ€ is equally important
  a principle as the â€œevolving standards of decency,â€ and â€œâ€˜it is a precept of
  justice that punishment for crime should be graduated and proportioned to [the]
  offense.â€™â€Â  Pittman, 373 S.C. at 564-65, 647 S.E.2d at 163 (quoting Atkins,
  536 U.S. at 311).Â  In order to establish that evolving standards of decency
  preclude his punishment, appellant bears the â€œâ€˜heavy burdenâ€™ of showing that our
  culture and laws emphatically and well nigh universally reject it.â€Â  Id. at 565, 647 S.E.2d at 164 (quoting Harris v. Wright, 93 F.3d 581, 583
  (1996)).
In State
  v. Standard, 351 S.C. 199, 569 S.E.2d 325 (2002), our supreme court found,
  based upon sentences imposed in other cases, that lengthy sentences or
  sentences of life without parole imposed upon juveniles do not violate
  contemporary standards of decency so as to constitute cruel and unusual
  punishment, and that an enhanced sentence based upon a prior â€œmost seriousâ€
  conviction for a crime which was committed as a juvenile does not offend
  evolving standards of decency so as to constitute cruel and unusual punishment. Id. Â at 205-06, 569 S.E.2d at 329.Â  Accordingly, Standardâ€™s sentence
  of LWOP based on a previous â€œmost seriousâ€ armed robbery conviction when he was
  seventeen and his subsequent â€œmost seriousâ€ conviction of burglary in the first
  degree did not violate the Eighth Amendment.
Our
  courts have also determined stiff penalties for drug crimes do not violate the
  constitutional prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment.Â Â  SeeÂ  State
    v. Brown, 303 S.C. 169, 172, 399 S.E.2d 593, 594 (1991) (holding sentence
  of 25 years without parole upon conviction of trafficking in cocaine was not
  cruel and unusual punishment); State v. Kiser, 288 S.C. 441, 443-44, 343
  S.E.2d 292, 293 (1986) (holding mandatory minimum sentence of 25 years in
  prison for trafficking in marijuana was not grossly out of proportion with
  severity of crime and, therefore, complied with cruel and unusual punishment
  clause).Â  Additionally, in considering the implications of drugs on our society
  today, the United States Supreme Court has noted as follows:

  Possession, use, and distribution of illegal drugs represent â€œone
    of the greatest problems affecting the health and welfare of our population.â€ Petitionerâ€™s suggestion that his
    crime was nonviolent and victimless, echoed by the dissent, is false to the
    point of absurdity. To the contrary, petitionerâ€™s crime threatened to cause
    grave harm to society.
  Quite apart from the pernicious effects on
    the individual who consumes illegal drugs, such drugs relate to crime in at
    least three ways: (1) A drug user may commit crime because of drug-induced
    changes in physiological functions, cognitive ability, and mood; (2) A drug
    user may commit crime in order to obtain money to buy drugs; and (3) A violent
    crime may occur as part of the drug business or culture. Â Studies bear out
    these possibilities and demonstrate a direct nexus between illegal drugs and
    crimes of violence.

Harmelin v.
  Michigan, 501 U.S. 957, 1002-03 (1991) (citations omitted).Â  Finally, the United States Supreme Court has
  also held a state is justified in punishing a recidivist more severely than it
  does a first offender.Â  Riggs v. California, 119 S.Ct. 890, 891 (1999).Â  Under
  recidivist sentencing schemes, the enhanced punishment imposed for a present
  offense is not to be viewed as an additional penalty for the earlier crimes,
  but instead as a stiffened penalty for the latest crime, which is considered to
  be an aggravated offense because it is a repetitive one.Â  Id. 
In
  light of our courtâ€™s decisions in finding sentences of LWOP imposed upon
  juveniles do not violate contemporary standards of decency so as to constitute
  cruel and unusual punishment and that an enhanced sentence based upon a prior â€œmost
  seriousâ€ conviction for a crime which was committed as a juvenile does not
  offend evolving standards of decency so as to constitute cruel and unusual
  punishment, that stiff penalties for drug crimes do not violate the
  constitutional prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment, and in
  consideration of the implications of drugs on our society today as noted by the
  United States Supreme Court in Harmelin,
  combined with the United States Supreme Courtâ€™s determination that a State is
  justified in punishing a recidivist more severely than it does a first
  offender, we find Williams has failed to
  meet his burden of establishing evolving standards of decency preclude his
  punishment, or that his sentence is disproportionate to the crime. Â 
For
  the foregoing reasons, Williamsâ€™ convictions and sentences are
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN,
  C.J., and GEATHERS, J., concur.


[1] We note our review of the video exhibit supports
  the officersâ€™ testimony.

title: State v. Mattison
description: In this criminal case, appellant appeals his convictions of murder, asssault and battery with intent to kill, and possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime asserting the trial court erred in refusing to instruct the jury (1) that prior knowledge a crime was to be committed is insufficient to establish guilt and (2) that mere association with a person who commits a crime is insufficient to establish guilt.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Amos Lamont
          Mattison, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4448
  Heard September 18, 2008 â€“ Filed October
22, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Deputy Chief Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, South Carolina
          Commission on Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, of
          Columbia; Â and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HUFF,
  J.:Â  Amos Lamont Mattison was convicted of murder, assault
  and battery with intent to kill (ABIK), and possession of a weapon during the
  commission of a violent crime. Â The trial court sentenced Mattison to life
  imprisonment without parole on the murder charge, one year consecutive on the
  weapon charge, and twenty years concurrent on the ABIK charge.Â  Mattison
  appeals, asserting the trial court erred in refusing to instruct the jury that
  prior knowledge a crime was to be committed is insufficient to establish guilt
  and that mere association with a person who commits a crime is insufficient to
  establish guilt.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
This case involves the shooting injury of
  Jose Garcia and shooting deaths of his brother, Roberto Garcia, and their
  cousin, Jorge Lemus.Â  The State set forth the theory that in August 2003,
  Mattison schemed with Britney Ervin to lure Jose, Roberto, and Jorge to a
  remote location to murder them and steal an automobile.Â  Evidence presented at
  trial through direct testimony and statements given to the police included
  differing versions of what occurred that day.
Jose testified that on the morning of August 23, 2003, his cousin
  Jorge awoke him and told him someone wanted to buy Joseâ€™s Chevy Impala car.Â 
  Thereafter, a black, skinny man, whom Jose later identified as Ervin, came to
  his home and Jose told him the amount of money he wanted for the car.Â  Ervin
  left, and came back five to ten minutes later requesting to test drive the car. Â Jose and Ervin left in the car, and as they approached a corner, Jose
  saw Mattison wave at them, but they did not pick up Mattison at that time.Â 
  Jose and Ervin then returned to Joseâ€™s home, and then Ervin left.Â  About five
  minutes later, Ervin returned, wanting to make a deal.Â  He indicated he had to
  go to his grandfatherâ€™s house to get money.Â  Jose and Ervin drove off to get
  the money, and Roberto and Jorge followed them in a Honda Passport automobile
  in order to bring Jose back home after he sold the car.Â  As they drove they saw
  Mattison at the same location as before, and Jose and Ervin stopped and picked up
  Mattison.Â  Mattison and Ervin talked and appeared to know each other.Â  They
  directed Jose down a dirt road, and although he hesitated to drive down it, he
  did so at the forceful insistence of Ervin.Â Â Â Â  
Mattison
  and Ervin exited the car and walked around the house.Â  They were gone about ten
  minutes.Â  Mattison returned to the car and began talking to Jose.Â  Mattison
  told Jose he did not want to go back around the house because Ervinâ€™s
  grandfather did not like him.Â  After waiting approximately fifteen minutes,
  Jose was about to leave, but Ervin came back from around the house and told
  Jose his grandfather was going to give him the money.Â  Ervin said he needed
  help with a tire, and Roberto went around the house with Ervin to assist him.Â 
  Jorge exited the Honda and approached Jose to ask what was happening.Â  Jose
  then heard a gunshot.Â  Jose and Mattison exited the Impala.Â  Mattison told Jose
  that Ervinâ€™s grandfather was crazy and he was shooting.Â  Jose, Jorge and
  Mattison then went around the house, where Jose observed Ervin with a gun in
  his hand, coming toward the three men.Â  When Jorge saw Ervin with the gun, he
  ran.Â  As Ervin chased Jorge, Mattison told Jose not to worry because he had a
  gun too, and he was going to help them.Â  Mattison then pulled out a handgun.Â 
  Ervin caught Jorge and brought him back.Â  The four then continued toward the
  back of the house, with Jose and Jorge in front followed by Ervin and then
  Mattison.Â  As they approached a building behind the house, Jose asked where his
  brother was.Â  Ervin put a gun to Joseâ€™s head and told him to keep walking.Â  
As they reached the corner, Jose heard his brother moaning and
  then saw him face down on the ground.Â  Jose told Mattison and Ervin to just
  take the cars and let him get his brother to a hospital.Â  Ervin then pointed
  the gun at Jose.Â  As Ervin raised the gun to shoot Jose, Jorge jumped on top of
  Ervin and Jose then jumped in, and a struggle ensued over Ervinâ€™s gun.Â  Jose
  looked up and saw Mattison standing in the same corner as before with his gun
  in his hands.Â  During the struggle over the gun with Ervin it fired, but did
  not hit Jose.Â  Ervin was trying to shoot Jose, and Ervin told Mattison, more
  than once, to shoot Jose.Â  Jose then heard a gunshot from Mattisonâ€™s direction
  and felt his shirt fly.Â  He turned and looked at Mattison, and saw him run.Â 
  Jose noticed Jorge was getting weaker and saw him fall to the ground.Â  After
  Ervin saw Mattison run away, he asked Jose to let go of the gun and stated he
  would do the same.Â  Jose did not, but eventually obtained control over the gun
  and Ervin then ran.Â  As Jose left to seek help, he noticed both the Chevy and
  the Honda were gone.
Jose suffered a bullet graze injury to his shoulder during the
  struggle.Â  Roberto and Jorge were transported to the hospital where both were
  eventually pronounced dead.Â  Roberto died from a gunshot wound to the abdomen
  and another to the pelvis.Â  Jorge died from a gunshot wound to the head.Â  The
  two bullets recovered from Roberto were fired from the caliber nine millimeter
  Luger gun that Jose had taken from Ervin in the struggle.Â  The bullet recovered
  from Jorge was a thirty-two caliber, fired from a different gun which was never
  found by the authorities.
Jose
  gave a statement to police describing his assailants as a fat guy and a skinny
  guy.Â  He identified Ervin, the one he described as skinny, from a photographic
  line-up after Ervin was arrested driving Joseâ€™s Chevy Impala.Â  Jose made an
  in-court identification of Mattison as the other man who rode in the back of
  his car and ultimately shot in his direction.Â  When asked if, seeing Mattison
  in the court room he would describe him as â€œthe fat guy,â€ Jose stated he would,
  noting that he had been wearing a loose shirt and that is why he described him
  as fat.
After his arrest, Ervin gave two statements to the authorities.Â 
  In his first, Ervin claimed Mattison asked him to help set up some Mexicans so
  he could rob them for their drugs.Â  He claimed Mattison told him to act like he
  wanted to purchase their car, and threatened Ervin to get his cooperation.Â 
  Ervin claimed after he directed them to his grandfatherâ€™s shop, Mattison told
  him to go to the back with him.Â  There, Mattison pointed a twenty-two caliber
  pistol at Ervin and told him to get the Mexicans.Â  Mattison gave Ervin a nine
  millimeter gun to use.Â  Mattison told Ervin to shoot the Mexicans, but he
  refused.Â  Mattison took the nine millimeter gun from Ervin and shot the
  Mexicans.Â  When Mattison started firing, Ervin ran.Â  Ervinâ€™s second statement
  indicated it was given to correct his first statement as to â€œhow the shooting
  went down.â€Â  There, Ervin stated that Mattison stayed with two of the Mexicans
  at the car while he walked to the shop with a short Mexican.Â  Ervin pulled out
  the nine millimeter gun, the Mexican tried to run, and he then shot him in the
  chest.Â  Ervin then walked up to him and shot him in the neck.Â  He did this
  because Mattison had told him the Mexicans had drugs in the house, and Mattison
  planned to kill them to steal the drugs.Â  As Ervin walked back to the others,
  Mattison had the twenty-two caliber gun pulled on the Mexicans.Â  Ervin pointed
  the nine millimeter at them and directed them to the back of the shop where he
  planned to kill them.Â  One of them saw the man Ervin had shot and began
  fighting Ervin.Â  The other one struggled with Ervin over the gun and the gun
  discharged.Â  When that happened, Mattison fired his gun.Â  One of the Mexicans
  got control over Ervinâ€™s pistol and Ervin ran.
At trial, Ervin denied telling the authorities much of what was in
  his two statements.Â  He also gave a different version of events, claiming that
  Mattison brought some Mexicans to his home that day to see if Ervin wanted to
  buy a car.Â  Ervin agreed to buy it, but it had a dent in the trunk and Mattison
  told him he knew where he could find another trunk.Â  Ervin, Mattison, and one
  of the Mexicans then followed behind two other Mexicans in the Honda to Ervinâ€™s
  grandfatherâ€™s property.Â  According to Ervinâ€™s trial testimony, Mattison asked
  Ervin to help him rob the Mexicans.Â  Mattison then took one of the Mexicans
  with him to the back of the shop.Â  Ervin heard some gun shots, and the other
  Mexicans ran up to him and asked what was happening.Â  Ervin told them he did
  not know.Â  Mattison ran back to the front, and Ervin then jumped in the Chevy
  and left.
Mattison did not testify at his trial.Â  A statement Mattison made
  was, however, read into the record.Â  Mattison claimed in his statement that
  Ervin brought a Mexican to his house trying to buy Mattisonâ€™s car in exchange
  for drugs.Â  Mattison stated he wanted money, not drugs.Â  Ervin indicated they
  would have to get the money from Ervinâ€™s grandfather.Â  Mattison rode with Ervin
  and the Mexican in a black car while a short, black man named Chuck or Bud
  followed in a gray car with two other Mexicans.Â  Ervin and the Mexican exited
  the car and went around the house, while the Mexicans from the gray car were
  with Mattison and Chuck remained in the gray car.Â  Mattison heard a â€œpop, pop,â€
  and said â€œletâ€™s go,â€ but the Mexican refused because of his brother.Â  They then
  ran to the back of the house.Â  Mattison heard â€œpop, popâ€ again, and he then
  took off running the other way.Â  As he ran up the driveway, he saw Ervin drive
  off in the black car.
After
  the State rested, the trial court granted Mattisonâ€™s directed verdict motions
  on the charge of possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent
  crime as related to the murder of Roberto, as well as on the charge of grand
  larceny of the Honda Passport.Â  At the close of the evidence, Mattison handed
  the court his requests to charge.Â  The trial court indicated it would cover the
  requests, but not exactly the way Mattison had asked.Â  When asked whether the
  charge would include â€œprior knowledge is not sufficient, mere association,â€ the
  court indicated it would not charge that. Â Counsel took exception to the
  courtâ€™s refusal to so charge.Â  The jury found Mattison guilty of the murder of
  Jorge and possession of a weapon during the commission of violent crime as
  related to Jorge, as well as the assault and battery with intent to kill Jose.Â 
  On the charge of the murder of Roberto, the jury was unable to reach a verdict,
  and the trial court declared a mistrial.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Mattison contends
  the trial court erred in refusing to charge the jury on prior knowledge and
  mere association.Â  He asserts he was entitled to a charge that prior knowledge
  a crime is going to be committed, without more, is insufficient to establish
  guilt.Â  He maintains there is evidence of record from Jose that Mattison was
  with him at the car when the shooting began and that Mattison wanted to leave
  immediately, but Jose was concerned about his brother.Â  Further, according to
  Mattisonâ€™s statement, upon hearing the shots, he â€œtook off running the other
  way.â€Â  Mattison contends it was important for the jury to understand that if it
  found Mattison was present at the scene, that his knowledge Ervin was going to
  commit a crime, without more, was insufficient to make him guilty of those
  crimes.Â  He further asserts it was important for the jury to understand that
  mere association with the perpetrator of the crime is also insufficient to
  prove guilt.Â  
The
  law to be charged must be determined from the evidence presented at trial.Â  State
    v. Knoten, 347 S.C. 296, 302, 555 S.E.2d 391, 394 (2001).Â  Generally, a
  trial court is required to charge only the current and correct law of South Carolina. Â Sheppard v. State, 357 S.C. 646, 665, 594 S.E.2d 462, 472 (2004).Â 
  A jury charge is correct if it contains the correct definition of the law when
  read as a whole. Â Id.Â  A trial court has a duty to give a requested
  instruction that is supported by the evidence and correctly states the law
  applicable to the issues. Â State v. Peer, 320 S.C. 546, 553, 466 S.E.2d
  375, 380 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  A trial court commits reversible error if it fails
  to give a requested charge on an issue raised by the evidence.Â  State v.
    Hill, 315 S.C. 260, 262, 433 S.E.2d 848, 849 (1993). Â A trial courtâ€™s
  decision regarding jury charges will not be reversed where the charges, as a
  whole, properly charged the law to be applied.Â  State v. Rye, 375 S.C.
  119, 123, 651 S.E.2d 321, 323 (2007).
Mere
  association with admitted members of a conspiracy is insufficient to tie other
  persons to the conspiracy. Â State v. Barroso, 328 S.C. 268, 272, 493
  S.E.2d 854, 856 (1997). Â Additionally, â€œ[m]ere presence and prior knowledge
  that a crime was going to be committed, without more, is insufficient to
  constitute guilt.â€Â  State v. Thompson, 374 S.C. 257, 262, 647 S.E.2d
  702, 705 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  â€œHowever, â€˜presence at the scene of a crime by
  pre-arrangement to aid, encourage, or abet in the perpetration of the crime
  constitutes guilt as a [principal].â€™â€Â  Id. Â Â 
Mattison
  points to the Thompson case for the proposition that prior knowledge
  that a crime is going to be committed, without more, is insufficient to
  constitute guilt.Â  However, the issue in Thompson was not whether the
  court failed to properly charge the jury, but whether Thompson was entitled to
  a directed verdict because the State failed to present any direct or
  substantial circumstantial evidence to show that Thompson was guilty of first
  degree burglary or attempted armed robbery, either as a principal or as an
  accomplice.Â  Further, this court noted in Thompson that while mere
  presence and prior knowledge, without more, are insufficient to establish
  guilt, presence at the scene of a crime by pre-arrangement to aid, encourage,
  or abet in the perpetration of the crime will constitute guilt as a principal.Â  Thompson, 374 S.C. at 262, 647 S.E.2d at 705.Â  
In State
  v. Kelsey, 331 S.C. 50, 502 S.E.2d 63 (1998), our supreme court held a
  charge to be sufficient, though the trial court failed to charge mere association.Â 
  The court ruled that the trial courtâ€™s charge was not misleading, it clearly
  explained the prosecution had to prove every element of the crime such that
  mere presence was not enough to sustain a conviction, and the trial judge
  extensively instructed the jury on the requisite criminal intent for each of
  the charged crimes.Â  Id. at 77, 502 S.E.2d at 76-77.
In
  the present case, the record shows the trial court charged the jury as follows:

  Ladies
    and Gentlemen, a principal in a crime is one who either in person perpetrates
    the crime or who being present aides and abets and assists the commission of that
    crime.Â  I charge you, Ladies and Gentlemen, that mere presence at the scene of
    a crime is not sufficient to convict.
  However,
    when one does an act in the presence of or with the assistance of another, the
    act is done by both.Â  Where two or more acted with a common design or intent is
    present at the commission of a crime, it does not matter by who (sic) the crime
    is committed, for all are guilty.
  Intent,
    however, Ladies and Gentlemen, is a necessary element of the offense.Â  There
    must have been a common design or attempt to commit the crime.Â  The crime must
    have been committed pursuant to the person aiding and abetting by some overt
    act.Â  Now, presence at the commission of a crime means to be sufficiently near
    so as to be able to aid and abet in its commission.
  Stated
    somewhat differently, Ladies and Gentlemen, is several, two or more persons
    pursuit (sic) to a common design to commit an unlawful act, set out together
    and each takes a part agreed upon or assigned to him to commit the act or which
    to watch at a proper distance at stations to prevent an appearance or surprise
    or to encourage the commission of unlawful act or to assist, if necessary,
    escape of those immediately engaged in the commission of the unlawful act,
    under any or all of these circumstances, if the unlawful act is committed, the
    act is one, the act of one is the act of all and all would be guilty.
  In other
    words, if several persons agree or conspire to commit a crime, each of those
    persons are criminally responsible for the acts of his confederates of which
    are done in the presence of the common purpose for which they combined.Â  The
    common purpose may have not included or involved killing anyone.
  But if
    in executing the common design and purpose, a common homicide is committed by
    one of the confederates and you, the jury, determine from all the evidence
    beyond a reasonable doubt that the homicide was a probable and natural
    consequence of the acts which was done in pursuit to the common design, then
    Ladies and Gentlemen, all who are present either actually or constructively and
    participated in the unlawful common design would be guilty.

The
  charge to the jury included a detailed instruction on aiding, abetting, and
  assisting in the commission of a crime through some overt act, and clearly indicated that mere presence alone was
  insufficient to sustain a conviction.Â  The charge noted that there must be a
  common design to commit an unlawful act, and that one present must aid, abet or
  assist in the commission of that crime in order to be found guilty. Â It
  explained the prosecution had to prove every element of the crime such that
  mere presence was not enough to sustain a conviction.Â  Implicit in the charge
  given to the jury was that mere knowledge a crime was going to occur, or mere
  association with one who commits a crime is insufficient to constitute guilt,
  but that Mattison must have, while present at the commission of the crime,
  aided, abetted, or assisted in the commission of the crime pursuant to a common
  design or purpose before a conviction could be had.Â  Accordingly, the trial
  courtâ€™s jury charge on the whole was proper.
For
  the foregoing reasons, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s charge to the
  jury.Â  Mattisonâ€™s convictions are therefore
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN,
  C.J., and GEATHERS, J., concur.

title: Sloan v. Greenville County
description: Greenville County appeals the trial courtâ€™s order striking down a portion of the previous county procurement code for being inconsistent with Section 11-35-50 of the South Carolina Code (2007).  We vacate the trial courtâ€™s order and dismiss this case as moot.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Edward D. Sloan, Jr., individually, and on behalf of all others
          similarly situated Respondent,
        v.
        Greenville County, a Political Subdivision  of South Carolina,
          Phyllis Henderson, Scott Case, Eric Bedingfield, Dozier Brooks, Joseph Dill,
          Cort Flint, Lottie Gibson, Judy Gilstrap, Mark Kingsbury, Xanthene Norris,
          Stephen Selby, and Robert Taylor, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4449
  Heard September 17, 2008 â€“ Filed October
22, 2008
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled January
7, 2009

VACATED AND DISMISSED


  
    
      
        Boyd B. Nicholson,
          Jr. and Joel M. Bondurant, both of Greenville, for Appellants.
        James G. Carpenter,
          of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PIEPER, J.:Â 
  Greenville County appeals the trial courtâ€™s order striking down a portion of
  the previous county procurement code for being inconsistent with Section
  11-35-50 of the South Carolina Code (2007).Â  We vacate the trial courtâ€™s order
and dismiss this case as moot.
FACTS
The relevant facts of this case are largely undisputed.Â  The
  trial court consolidated four cases by Edward A. Sloan (Sloan) challenging
  procurements made by Greenville County (County) between August 2002 and March
  2004, which utilized the competitive sealed proposal (Proposal) procurement
  method rather than the competitive sealed bidding (Bidding) method.Â  The
  gravamen of Sloanâ€™s action was to declare sections of the former Greenville County
  Procurement Code (GCPC) unlawful for allowing the determination to use
  Proposals as an alternative to the preferred procurement method of Bidding
  without memorializing or justifying the decision in writing, regardless of
whether the GCPC includes such a writing requirement.Â  
The previous GCPC provided in part as follows:
Â§ 7-304 Methods of
Source Selection.
Unless
  otherwise required by law, all County contracts shall be awarded by competitive
  sealed bidding, pursuant to Â§ 7-305 (Competitive Sealed Bidding), except as
provided herein:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (2)
Section 7-307 (Competitive Sealed Proposals).
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
Â§ 7-305 Competitive
Sealed Bidding.

  (1) Conditions
    for Use.Â  Contracts amounting to $25,000 or more shall be awarded by
    competitive bidding except as otherwise provided in Â§ 7-304 (Methods of Source
    Selection).

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
Â§ 7-307 Competitive
Sealed Proposals.

  (1) Conditions
    for use. When the Purchasing Manager determines that the use of competitive
    sealed bidding is either not practicable or not advantageous to the County, a
    contract may be entered into by use of the competitive sealed proposals method.

Unlike the South Carolina Procurement Code or the South Carolina Local
  Model Procurement Code, the GCPC did not require the procurement officerâ€™s
determination to use Proposals rather than Bidding to be in writing.

  Section 11-35-50 of the South Carolina Code (2007) states in
    part as follows:
  Political
    subdivisions required to develop and adopt procurement laws. 
  All
    political subdivisions of the State shall adopt ordinances or procedures
    embodying sound principles of appropriately competitive procurement no later
    than July 1, 1983.Â  The Budget and Control Board, in cooperation with the
    Procurement Policy Committee and subdivisions concerned, shall create a task
    force to draft model ordinances, regulations, and manuals for consideration by
    the political subdivisions . . . .Â  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 11-35-50 (2007).
On November 18, 2004, the parties stipulated to
consolidation of all four claims to be decided on the following two issues:

  (1)Â Â Â Â  Whether the Countyâ€™s Procurement Code requires a written determination
    in order for the County to use the [Proposal] procurement method, and
    by extension, whether the lack of a written determination for these
    projects in which the County used the [Proposal] method violated the
    Countyâ€™s procurement Code; and 
  (2)Â Â Â Â  If the Countyâ€™s Procurement Code does not require a written determination
    in order to use the [Proposal] procurement method, does it violate State
    law, and in particular, South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 11- 35-50?

After the trial court hearing on December 3, 2004, but before
  the order was issued on January 8, 2007, the County amended the GCPC on October
  17, 2006.Â  The new GCPC section titled â€œMethods of Source Selectionâ€ now reads
in part as follows:

  Unless
    otherwise required by law, all County contracts amounting to $25,000 or more
    shall be awarded by competitive sealed bidding, pursuant to Â§ 3-202
    (Competitive Sealed Bidding), or by competitive sealed proposals, pursuant
    to Â§ 3-204 (Competitive Sealed Proposals), whichever is determined to be
    more advantageous to the County . . . .

As such, the amended GCPC differs from the previous version because,
  among other things, it now has two equally preferred methods of procurement for
source selection, Bidding and Proposals.
On January 8, 2007, the trial court found that the claims
  were moot on the basis that all of the contracts involved were either completed
  or cancelled; however, citing the public interest exception to the mootness
  doctrine, the trial court proceeded to rule on whether the former GCPC embodied
  sound principles of appropriately competitive procurement by not requiring a
  determination to be in writing before using the Proposal method rather than the
  preferred method of Bidding.Â  The court concluded that the former version of
  the GCPC did not â€œembody sound principles of appropriately competitiveâ€
  procurement because it failed to require a determination in writing before the
  use of Proposals rather than the preferred method of Bidding.Â  This appeal
followed.
ISSUES ON APPEAL

  I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Did the Greenville County Procurement Code violate Â§ 11-35-50
    when the GCPCâ€™s sealed proposal method of procurement set forth a procedure
    that even the plaintiff acknowledged was appropriately competitive, but
    did not require a written determination to document why this method was
    chosen?
  II.Â Â Â Â Â  Whether the trial court was correct to decide the issue above
    â€œfor future  guidanceâ€ under the public importance exception to mootness, when Â  the
    preference for sealed bids that necessarily forms the basis of the Â  written
    determination requirement no longer exists?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œA suit for declaratory judgment is neither legal nor
  equitable, but is determined by the nature of the underlying issue.â€ Doe v.
    South Carolina Med. Malpractice Liab. Joint Underwriting Assâ€™n, 347 S.C.
  642, 645, 557 S.E.2d 670, 672 (2001) (internal citation omitted).Â  To make this
  determination, an appellate court must look to the essential character of the
  cause of action.Â  Barnacle Broad., Inc. v. Baker Broad., Inc., 343 S.C.
  140, 146, 538 S.E.2d 672, 675 (Ct. App. 2000). The character of the action is
  generally ascertained from the body of the complaint, but when necessary, resort
  may also be had to the prayer for relief and any other facts and circumstances
  which throw light upon the main purpose of the action.Â  Low Country Open Land
    Trust v. Charleston S. Univ., 376 S.C. 399, 406, 656 S.E.2d 775, 779 (Ct.
  App. 2008).Â  The issue of statutory interpretation is a question of law for the
  court. Â Catawba Indian Tribe of South Carolina v. State, 372 S.C. 519,
  524, 642 S.E.2d 751, 753 (2007).Â  We are free to decide questions of law with
no deference to the trial court.Â  Id.
DISCUSSION
We first address the issue of mootness
since this issue necessarily affects our disposition of this case.
The court does not concern itself with moot or
  speculative questions. Sloan v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., Op. No.
  26534 (S.C. Filed Aug. 25, 2008) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 33 at 43). Â An
  appellate court will not pass judgment on moot and academic questions; it will
  not adjudicate a matter when no actual controversy capable of specific relief
  exists. Â Curtis v. State, 345 S.C. 557, 567, 549 S.E.2d 591, 596
  (2001).Â  A case becomes moot when judgment, if rendered, will have no practical
  legal effect upon the existing controversy.Â  Id.Â  Mootness also arises
  when some event occurs making it impossible for the reviewing court to grant
effectual relief.Â  Id.
However, there are three exceptions to the mootness
  doctrine.  Id. at 568, 549 S.E.2d at 596.  First, if the issue
  raised is capable of repetition but generally will evade review, the appellate
  court can take jurisdiction.  Id.; see also Sloan v.
    South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 365 S.C. 299, 303, 618 S.E.2d 876,
  878 (2005); Byrd v. Irmo High Sch., 321 S.C. 426, 431, 468 S.E.2d
  861, 864 (1996).Â  â€œSecond, an appellate court may decide questions of
  imperative and manifest urgency to establish a rule for future conduct in
  matters of important public interest.â€  Curtis, 345 S.C. at 568,
  549 S.E.2d at 596 (emphasis added).  Application of the public interest
  exception requires the question at issue to be (1) of â€œpublic importance,â€ and (2) of â€œimperative and manifest urgency.â€ Â See Sloan v. Greenville County,
  361 S.C. 568, 570-71, 606 S.E.2d 464, 465-66 (2004).Â  Third, â€œif a decision by
  the trial court may affect future events, or have collateral consequences for
  the parties, an appeal from that decision is not moot, even though the
  appellate court cannot give effective relief in the present case.â€  Curtis,
  345 S.C. at 568, 549 S.E.2d at 596; accord Sloan, 365 S.C. at
  303, 618 S.E.2d at 878.Â  The utilization of an exception under the mootness
  doctrine is flexible and discretionary pursuant to South Carolina
  jurisprudence, not a mechanical rule that is automatically invoked.[1]Â  Compare,
    e.g., Sloan v. Greenville County, 356 S.C. 531, 553-55, 590 S.E.2d 338,
350-51, with Sloan, 361 S.C. at 571-72, 606 S.E.2d at 468; cf. 1A C.J.S. Actions Â§78 (2008).
Neither party has challenged the courtâ€™s
  preliminary conclusion that these cases are moot since the contracts were
  already completed or cancelled.[2]Â 
  Therefore that conclusion, right or wrong, is the law of the case. Â See Sloan,
  365 S.C. at 307, 618 S.E.2d at 880 (â€œ[A]n unappealed ruling becomes the law of
  the case, and the appellate court must assume the ruling was correct.â€)
  (quoting Town of Mt. Pleasant v. Jones, 335 S.C. 295, 298-99, 516 S.E.2d
  468, 470 (Ct. App. 1999)). Â Thus, the next question before us is whether this
  case is suitable for discretionary review of the issue presented under the
public interest exception to the mootness doctrine.[3]
County contends that since the GCPC no longer contains
  the preference for sealed bids that necessarily formed the basis of the trial
  courtâ€™s order, the trial court erred in determining that the case should be
decided under the public interest exception to mootness.Â  We agree.
The trial court found the case moot for the initial
  reason that the contracts at issue had already been performed or cancelled; it
  then found the public interest exception applied to that point of mootness.Â  However,
  the court did not fully address the public interest exception of the mootness
  doctrine to the suit after the change in the GCPC was brought to its attention;
  specifically, the trial court failed to address whether the suit remained one
  of â€œimperative and manifest urgencyâ€ after passage of the amended ordinance. Â See Sloan v. Friends of the Hunley, Inc., 369 S.C. 20, 27, 630 S.E.2d 474,
  478 (2006) (â€œ[T]he issue must present a question of imperative and manifest
  urgency requiring the establishment of a rule for future guidance in â€˜matters
  of important public interest.â€™Â  This evaluation must be made based on the facts
  of each individual situation.â€) (internal citation omitted). Â Here, after
  opining in a footnote that its analysis of the â€œpublic importanceâ€ exception would
  not change due to passage of the amended ordinance, the trial court â€œ[found] it
  necessary to go ahead and rule on the issue of whether such a determination
  must be in writing under the former version of the code.â€ (emphasis
  added). Â Therefore, the second prong of the public interest exception was never
  satisfied; the trial court failed to consider the impact of the amended
  ordinance on the suit through the lens of â€œimperative and manifest urgency,â€
  and erred in utilizing that exception to review the issue presented under the
previous ordinance.[4]
Sloan also argues there is an imperative and manifest
  urgency compelling this court to find Â§ 11-35-50 requires a written
  determination whenever a political subdivision selects the Proposal method over
  Bidding, regardless of whether the political subdivision designates the two
  methods as equally preferable, in order for the procurement to be
  â€œappropriately competitive.â€Â  As previously indicated, although the trial court
  briefly acknowledged this supplementary argument in a footnote of its opinion,
  it specifically refused to rule upon the issue in regard to the amended version
  of the GCPC. Â We find the record before us insufficiently developed to exercise
  our discretion under a mootness exception to address Sloanâ€™s ancillary argument
  regarding co-preferred methods of procurement. Â Moreover, we take judicial
  notice of our own docket and note that this very issue is currently on appeal
  in Sloan v. Greenville Hospital System, et al., Case Nos. 03-CP-23-3785,
  04-CP-23-5223, and 05-CP-23-0586 (appeal filed June 12, 2008).Â  Sloan
  acknowledges this fact in his appellate brief.Â  In that case, one of the main issues
  litigated and ruled upon was whether a written determination is required
  to select Proposals over Bidding when both are co-preferred procurement
  methods; as such, that case, as opposed to this case, is arguably more suitable
for review and adjudication of the issue. Â 
CONCLUSION
Due to the significant change in the ordinance, we
  find it unnecessary to decide the issue presented to the trial court of whether
  the Countyâ€™s former procurement code was valid; passing judgment upon this
  matter would only result in an advisory opinion on the application of an
  obsolete procurement ordinance to completed or cancelled contracts. Â We also
  decline to address Sloanâ€™s alternate argument under the amended ordinance since
the trial court never addressed the effect of the amended ordinance.
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s order is vacated and
the case is dismissed as moot. 
VACATED AND DISMISSED.


[1] Sloan conceded at oral argument that application of
  an exception to the mootness doctrine is discretionary rather than mandatory by
an appellate court.
[2] Both parties agree in their briefs that the four
cases at issue were moot at the time of the final hearing. 
[3] The public interest exception was the only exception
asserted to the trial court.
[4] Additionally, we note this court has provided some
  judicial guidance as to the meaning of Â§ 11-35-50 in Glasscock Co. v. Sumter
    County, 361 S.C. 483, 604 S.E.2d 718 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Id. at 490,
  604 S.E.2d at 721 (stating Â§ 11-35-50 does not mandate or require local
  governments to adopt specific methods of procurement or the process by which to
  apply them, and that it â€œclearly was intended to afford local governments
  needed flexibility to determine what is â€˜appropriately competitiveâ€™ in light of
  the public business they must transact.â€); see also Sloan, 361
  S.C. at 571-72, 606 S.E.2d at 466 (holding there is no imperative or manifest
  urgency in obtaining an advisory opinion on the application of an obsolete
  procurement ordinance to completed projects when the ordinance was subsequently
  altered addressing the existing controversy, and when judicial guidance on the
  matter already exists).Â  Because this finding is not dispositive of our
decision herein, we need not reach this issue.

title: S.C. Coastal Conservation League v. S.C. Department of Health and Environmental Control
description: In this civil action, did the Administrative Law Court judge err by (1) concluding appellant failed to timely file a request for final review of a permit application before the DHEC Board pursuant to SC Code Ann. Â§ 44-1-60(E) and (2) denying appellantâ€™s motion to reconsider as untimely?  In this appeal from the Administrative Law Court, the appellant contends the ALC judge erred by dismissing its contested case challenging SCDHECâ€™s grant of a permit to SCSPA for a marine cargo terminal and by denying its subsequent motion for reconsideration.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        South
          Carolina Coastal
            Conservation League, Appellant,
        v.
        South
          Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control and South Carolina
          State Ports Authority, Respondents.
      
    
  



  
    
      
        South
          Carolina Coastal
            Conservation League, Appellant,
        v.
        South
          Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control, South Carolina
          Department of Transportation, and South Carolina State Ports Authority, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From The Administrative Law Court
  Â John D. Geathers, Administrative Law
Judge

Opinion No. 4450
  Heard October 21, 2008 -Â  Filed October
23, 2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        J. Blanding Holman, IV and W. Jefferson Leath, both of Charleston, for Appellant.
        Sara P. Bazemore and Carlisle Roberts, Jr., both of Columbia, and Evander
          Whitehead, of North Charleston, for Respondent South Carolina Department of
          Health and Environmental Control.Â  
        Deborah B. Durden, of Columbia, for Respondent South Carolina
          Department of Transportation.Â  
        Mitchell Willoughby and Randolph R. Lowell, both of Columbia, and Philip L. Lawrence, of Charleston, for Respondent South Carolina State Ports
          Authority.Â  
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  The South Carolina Coastal Conservation League (â€œCoastalâ€) appeals
  the decision of the Administrative Law Court (â€œALCâ€) to grant orders of
  dismissal in contested case hearings regarding the bestowal of permits to the
  South Carolina State Ports Authority (â€œSPAâ€) and the South Carolina Department
  of Transportation (â€œDOT) and the issuance of orders of dismissal denying Coastalâ€™s
  motions for reconsideration.Â  Coastal contends the ALC judge erred by (1)
  misinterpreting the pertinent appeals period for agency decisions, (2) failing
  to properly invoke jurisdiction over the matter, (3) ignoring issues of waiver,
  estoppel, and equitable tolling, (4) violating due process rights through a
  mistaken statutory interpretation, and (5) abusing the courtâ€™s discretion by
  denying the motions for reconsideration.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The South Carolina
  State Ports Authority and the South Carolina Department of Transportation each
  filed permit applications with the South Carolina Department of Health and
  Environmental Control (â€œDHECâ€) regarding a proposed project to develop the area
  around the former Charleston Naval Base.Â  The goal of the project was the
  construction of a 300-acre marine container terminal.Â  Additionally, in order
  to provide access to the facility, the DOT intended to construct an access road
  linking the terminal with Interstate 26.Â Â  
DHEC issued public
  notice of the pendency of the applications and conducted hearings to receive
  comments from concerned citizens and interested parties regarding the permits.Â 
  The South Carolina Coastal Conservation League participated in these hearings
  and provided comments to DHEC expressing concernment over the potential
  negative effects that might flow from the construction.Â  Although Coastal filed
  comments with DHEC objecting to the permits, the record contains no evidence
  Coastal filed a request for notification from DHEC when a decision was reached
  on each of the applications.Â  
After conducting an
  evaluation of the proposal with consideration given to all information received
  from the public hearings, including the comments from Coastal, DHEC department
  staff granted all necessary permits requested for the project.Â  DHEC issued a
  permit to the SPA on October 30, 2006, and sent a copy through certified mail
  the following day, October 31, 2006.Â  Based on an error in the original permit,
  a revised permit was sent to the SPA on November 2, 2006.Â  On November 13, 2006,
  DHEC mailed a permit to the DOT via certified mail.Â  Both permits consisted of
  a critical area permit, a coastal zone consistency certification, and a Section
  401 water quality certification.Â  
In response to the
  issuance of these permits, multiple requests for a final review before the South
  Carolina Board of Health and Environmental Control (â€œDHEC Boardâ€) were filed.Â 
  The SPA filed for review of its permit on November 13, 2006.Â  Coastal filed a
  request regarding the SPA permit on November 20, 2006, and a motion to
  intervene in the SPAâ€™s request on December 6, 2006.Â  Additionally, Coastal
  filed a request for review concerning the DOT permit on November 30, 2006.Â  
The DHEC Board scheduled
  a final hearing to address the two permits for January 11, 2007.Â  On the day of
  the hearing, the SPA and DHEC staff announced an agreement had been reached
  regarding the SPAâ€™s permit.Â  The DHEC Board continued with the hearing in order
  to address Coastalâ€™s concerns and ignored objections from the SPA and DHEC
  staff that Coastalâ€™s requests for hearings were not timely filed.Â  In its order
  dated February 8, 2007, the DHEC Board issued the final agency decision granting
  the permits with only minor revisions to the DOT permit and with the
  agreed-upon changes to the SPA permit.Â  
Based on the
  decision of the DHEC Board, Coastal requested contested case hearings with the Administrative Law Court on March 9, 2007, for the SPA and DOT permits.Â  The ALC judge
  granted the SPAâ€™s motion to intervene with the consent of all parties.Â  Subsequently,
  the SPA filed motions to dismiss in both cases on the grounds that the ALC
  lacked jurisdiction to decide the matters due to Coastalâ€™s failure to timely
  file for review before the DHEC Board.Â  On July 2, the ALC judge conducted a
  hearing on the motions for dismissal.Â  
On September 4,
  2007, the ALC judge issued an order dismissing both cases.Â  In reaching this
  decision, the ALC judge concluded:

  S.C.
    Code Ann. Â§ 44-1-60(E) clearly provides the exclusive mechanism for review
    under the facts and circumstances presented in this case.Â  The fifteen-day time
    period within which to file a request for final review begins upon mailing the
    notice of the staff decision to the applicant.Â  It is undisputed that the
    League failed to file a request for final review with the Board within the
    statutory time frame.Â  The arguments offered by the League to excuse this
    failure to timely file are unavailing.Â  Therefore, this Court lacks
    jurisdiction over this matter, and this case must be dismissed.Â  

Following the
  issuance of the order, Coastal filed a motion for reconsideration with the ALC
  on September 18, 2007.Â  The motion was denied as untimely.Â  Coastal filed a
  second motion for reconsideration requesting a review of the original ALC order
  and the first order for reconsideration.Â  On October 1, 2007, Coastal filed a
  notice of appeal with the Court of Appeals.Â  Based on the pending appeal, the
  ALC issued an order declining to rule on the second motion for reconsideration
  and to make any additional rulings on the controversy.Â Â Â  
ISSUES
1.Â  Did Coastalâ€™s
  dual requests for final review before the DHEC Board, which were not filed
  within fifteen days from the date notice was mailed to the permit applicants,
  prevent the Administrative Law Court from conducting a contested case hearing
  on the matter?
2.Â  Did principles
  of waiver, estoppel, and equitable tolling entitle Coastal to a contested case
  hearing before the Administrative Law Court regardless of the timeliness of the
  request for final review?
3.Â  Did the Administrative Law Court deny Coastal due process rights through its application of Section
  44-1-60?
4.Â  Did the Administrative Law Court abuse its discretion by striking Coastalâ€™s Motion for
  Reconsideration as untimely?
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina
  Administrative Procedures Act (APA) articulates the standard for judicial
  review of cases decided by the ALC.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-610(B)-(C)
  (Supp. 2007); Olson v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 379

    person shall be finally bound by a judicial or quasi-judicial decision of an
    administrative agency affecting private rights except on due notice and an
    opportunity to be heard; nor shall he be subject to the same person for both
    prosecution and adjudication; nor shall he be deprived of liberty or property
    unless by a mode of procedure prescribed by the General Assembly, and he shall
    have in all such instances the right to judicial review.Â  

S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 22.Â  The
  State Supreme Court has interpreted this provision to provide â€œpersons the
  right to notice and an opportunity to be heard by an administrative agency,
  even when a contested case under the APA is not involved.â€Â  Ross v. Med.
    Univ. of S.C., 328 S.C. 51, 68, 492 S.E.2d 62, 71 (1997) (citing Stono  River Envtl. Prot. Assâ€™n v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl.
      Control, 305 S.C. 90, 94, 406 S.E.2d 340, 342 (1991)); accord Kurschner
        v. City of Camden Planning Commâ€™n, 376 S.C. 165, 171, 656 S.E.2d 346, 350
  (2008) (â€œThe fundamental requirements of due process include notice, an
opportunity to be heard in a meaningful way, and judicial review.â€).Â  
â€œDue process
  requires (1) adequate notice; (2) adequate opportunity for a hearing; (3) the
  right to introduce evidence; and (4) the right to confront and cross-examine
  witnesses.â€Â  Clear Channel Outdoor v. City of Myrtle Beach, 372 S.C.
  230, 235, 642 S.E.2d 565, 567 (2007) (citing In re Vora, 354 S.C. 590,
  595, 582 S.E.2d 413, 416 (2003)); accord Dangerfield v. State,
  376 S.C. 176, 179, 656 S.E.2d 353, 354 (2008) (â€œThe procedural component of the
  state and federal due process clauses requires the individual whose property or
  liberty interests are affected to have received adequate notice of the
  proceeding, the opportunity to be heard in person, the opportunity to introduce
  evidence, the right to confront and cross-examine adverse witnesses, and the
  right to meaningful judicial review.â€)Â  An interested party must be given
  notice â€œreasonably calculated under all circumstances to apprise interested
  parties of the pendency of the action and afford them an opportunity to present
  their objections.â€Â  Blanton v. Stathos, 351 S.C. 534, 542, 570 S.E.2d
  565, 569 (2002) (citing Mullane v. Cent. Hanover Bank & Trust Co.,
  339 U.S. 306, 314 (1950); Murdock v. Murdock, 338 S.C. 322, 334, 526
  S.E.2d 241, 248 (Ct. App. 1999)).Â  â€œ â€˜To prove the denial of due process in an
  administrative proceeding, a party must show that it was substantially
  prejudiced by the administrative process.â€™ â€Â  Leventis v. S.C. Depâ€™t of
    Health & Envtl. Control, 340 S.C. 118, 131-132, 530 S.E.2d 643, 650
  (Ct. App. 2000) (quoting Ogburn-Matthews v. Loblolly Partners, 332 S.C.
  551, 561, 505 S.E.2d 598, 603 (Ct. App. 1998), overruled on other grounds by Brown v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 348 S.C. 507, 560
S.E.2d 410 (2002)).Â  
In response to
  the SPAâ€™s motions to dismiss the contested case hearings before the ALC,
  Coastal filed a response maintaining it would be denied due process of law if
  the contested case hearings were not held.Â  The ALC judge denied the motions
and, in the Order of Dismissal, held:Â  

  The
    League received the notice due to it when (1) public notice of SPAâ€™s permit
    application was provided; and (2) the General Assembly enacted the requirement
    in Section 44-1-60(E) that affected persons must affirmatively request to be
    notified of the staff decision on the permit application when it is issued.Â  See Smothers v. United States Fid. & Guar. Co., 322 S.C. 207, 210-211,
    470 S.E.2d 858, 860 (1996) (â€œEveryone is presumed to have knowledge of the law
    and must exercise reasonable care to protect his interests.â€)

We agree with the
  ALC judge.Â  While Coastal has a constitutional right to due process of law,
  including a right to notice and a meaningful opportunity to be heard, Coastal
  failed to take the necessary steps outlined in the statutory procedure of Section
  44-1-60 to protect these rights.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-1-60(E).Â  A
  party â€œcannot complain of a due process violation if he has recourse to a
  constitutionally sufficient administrative procedure but merely declines or
  fails to take advantage of it.â€Â  Zaman v. S.C. State Bd. of Med. Examâ€™rs,
305 S.C. 281, 285, 408 S.E.2d 213, 215 (1991).Â  
Coastal received
  public notice of the pending permit applications and participated in public
  hearings.Â  Additionally, Coastal expressed concern to DHEC in comment letters.Â 
  However, Coastal failed to comply with the established administrative
  procedures that would have entitled it to mailed notification from DHEC when
  the approved permits were mailed to the SPA and the DOT.Â  Through Section
  44-1-60(E), the General Assembly provided Coastal with the means to receive
  notice, but Coastal declined to avail itself of the statutorily-mandated
  protocol.Â  Coastalâ€™s due process rights were not violated by the ALC judgeâ€™s
interpretation of the statute.Â  
V.Â  Abuse of Discretion
Regarding the Timeliness of Coastalâ€™s Motions for Reconsideration
Coastal asserts the
  ALC judge erred in denying its motions for reconsideration of the dismissal
  orders.Â  We agree with the merits of the ALC judgeâ€™s decision to dismiss both
  contested cases.Â  Based on our ruling in this matter, it is unnecessary for
  this Court to further address the issue of abuse of discretion.Â  See Whiteside
    v. Cherokee County School Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886,
  889 (1993) (holding courts need not address remaining exceptions when the resolution
  of a prior issue is dispositive of the case).Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the
  foregoing analysis and reasons, the orders issued by the administrative law
  judge are
AFFIRMED.Â  
KONDUROS,
  J., and CURETON, A.J., concurring.Â

title: State v. Dickey
description: In this criminal action, we determine whether the trial court erred in refusing to hold defendant established self-defense as a matter of law; whether the trial court erred in instructing the jury on voluntary manslaughter; whether the trial court, when instructing the jury on self-defense, properly charged the jury on curtilage, the duty to retreat and the right to act on appearances; and whether the trial courtâ€™s â€œillustrationâ€ of voluntary manslaughter during the jury charge was an improper comment on the facts of the case.
