THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Jason Michael
          Dickey, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
  Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge

Opinion No.Â Â  4451
  Heard October 7, 2008 â€“ Filed October 29,
2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Laura C. Tesh, of Columbia and Lourie A. Salley, of Lexington, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior
          Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, Office of the Attorney General
          and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.: Jason Michael Dickey was convicted of
  voluntary manslaughter after he shot and killed Josh Boot on the sidewalk
  outside the apartment building where Dickey lived and worked as a security
  guard.Â  Dickey makes several arguments on appeal.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In
  April 2004, Dickey was working as the night watchman at the Cornell Arms
  apartments in Columbia, where he also resided.Â  Although not required by his
  employer for his duties, Dickey carried a loaded pistol, for which he held a
  valid permit. 
On
  April 29, 2004, Boot and Alex Stroud (Stroud) were tailgating outside a Jimmy
  Buffett concert at the Colonial Center, a few blocks from the Cornell Arms
  apartments.Â  According to Stroud, Boot consumed approximately twenty beers and
  several shots of liquor that evening.Â  Stroud and Boot met two ladies outside
  the concert, Amanda McGariggle (McGariggle) and Tara West (West), both of whom
  resided at the Cornell Arms apartments.Â  After a few hours of drinking together
  outside the Colonial Center, Boot and Stroud accompanied the two ladies back to
  their apartment.Â  While West and Stroud adjourned to Westâ€™s bedroom, Boot and
  McGariggle remained on the sofa in the living room of the apartment.Â  As they
  sat on the sofa, apparently close to an open window, a neighbor from the sixth
  floor threw a water balloon[1] down into the ladiesâ€™ apartment, splashing Boot.Â  Boot became angry and stormed
  out of the apartment.Â  He then went upstairs to the floors above and began
  randomly knocking on the doors of other tenants.
At
  this point, McGariggle went to the lobby and asked Dickey, who was the security
  guard on duty that night, to evict Boot from her apartment.Â  Dickey came to the
  apartment where he found Boot upset and intoxicated.Â  Dickey told Boot to leave
  or else he would call the police. Boot was indignant, hurling obscenities and
  insults at Dickey and making physical threats to him as he slammed the door to
  the apartment. According to West and McGariggle, Dickey looked angry during the
  encounter but remained calm and did not try to threaten or grab Boot.Â  As he
  stood outside the door, Dickey proceeded to call the police to report the
  disturbance. 
Meanwhile,
  back in the apartment, Stroud calmed Boot down and convinced Boot they should
  leave. As the two exited the apartment, they passed Dickey in the hallway.Â 
  According to Stroud, Dickey and Boot â€œstared each other down,â€ but no words
  were exchanged.Â  Boot and Stroud took the elevator down to the lobby while
  Dickey took the stairs down to meet them. As Boot and Stroud walked to the
  front door to exit, Dickey followed behind them.Â  Again, no words were
  exchanged. Â Boot and Stroud exited the building.Â  Dickey followed the two out
  the building, stood on the Cornell Arms front doormat, and watched them walk
  away. Â Boot then turned around and walked back in the direction of Dickey.Â  
At
  this point, the testimony of the witnesses varies substantially.Â  Stroud
  testified he was â€œright besideâ€ Boot as Boot advanced towards Dickey and asked
  Dickey, â€œ[W]hy the f__ was he following [them]?â€ Stroud then stated when Boot
  turned around to say something towards Dickey, Dickey shot Boot three times.Â 
  Dickey, on the other hand, testified the two turned towards him and made
  threats they were going to â€œkick his a__,â€ and called him a â€œfat f__â€ among
  other things.Â  Dickey testified he told them, again, he just wanted them to
  leave. Dickey stated he was afraid and felt â€œ[he] was outnumbered and [he]
  realized they were covering ground too fast for [him] to get back in the
  building.â€ Â Dickey went on to say he reached into his pocket and exposed his
  pistol, causing both men to stop advancing temporarily. Dickey then claimed
  Boot said, â€œf__ it, letâ€™s do it,â€ and reached under his shirt and stepped
  toward Dickey. Â Believing Boot to have a concealed weapon under his shirt,
  Dickey fired three shots, killing Boot. 
Immediately,
  Dickey called 911. When the police arrived, Dickey told the officer about his
  pistol and that he had a concealed weapon permit. Dickey told the officer he
  shot Boot after Boot had come at him with a bottle he had hidden under his
  shirt. Â Crime scene investigators found a broken liquor bottle near the scene
  of the shooting with a smear of Bootâ€™s blood on it.Â  
Dickey
  was indicted for murder and tried before a jury in September 2006.Â  At the
  close of the Stateâ€™s evidence, defense counsel moved for a directed verdict of
  acquittal on the ground of self-defense. The motion was denied.Â  Defense
  counsel renewed the motion for directed verdict at the close of all evidence.
  Thereafter, the trial court instructed the jury on murder, voluntary
  manslaughter, and self-defense. After the trial court charged the jury, defense
  counsel argued the trial court did not adequately charge the jury on either the
  right to act on appearances or the duty to retreat and objected to the refusal
  to charge the requested instructions on curtilage.Â  During the instruction on
  voluntary manslaughter, the trial judge stated to the jury:

  By way
    of illustration, and I would point out this is by illustration alone, that if
    an unjustifiable assault is made with violence with the circumstances of
    indignity upon a manâ€™s person and the party so assaulted kills the aggressor
    the crime will be reduced to manslaughter.Â  

The jury returned a verdict
  of voluntary manslaughter.Â  Dickey was sentenced to sixteen years imprisonment. 
ISSUES

  A.   Whether the trial court erred in
    refusing to grant a directed verdict that Dickey acted in self defense as a
    matter of law?
  B.   Whether the trial court, in its
    instructions on self-defense, properly charged the jury on curtilage, the duty
    to retreat, and the right to act on appearances?
  C.   Whether the trial court erred in
    charging the jury on voluntary manslaughter in light of the evidence presented
    at trial?
  D.   Whether the trial courtâ€™s
    â€œillustrationâ€ to the jury of voluntary manslaughter was an improper comment on
    the facts?
  E.    Whether the trial court erred in
    refusing to retroactively apply the â€œStand Your Groundâ€ law to this case?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In
  criminal cases, this Court reviews errors of law only.Â  State v. Miller,
  375 S.C. 370, 378, 652 S.E.2d 444, 448 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  Thus, we are bound by
  the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
A.   Directed Verdict of
  Self-Defense as a Matter of Law
Dickey
  argues under State v. Hendrix, 270 S.C. 653, 244 S.E.2d 503 (1978), the
  trial court should have directed a verdict of acquittal because the State
  failed to provide evidence to negate his claim of self-defense as a matter of
  law.Â  We disagree.
The
  basic definition of when a person is justified in using deadly force in
  self-defense is comprised of four elements: 

  (1) That he was without fault in
    bringing on the difficulty, (2) That he actually believed he was in imminent
    danger of losing his life or of sustaining serious bodily injury [], or he
    actually was in imminent danger of losing his life or of sustaining serious
    bodily injury, (3) If his defense is based on his actual belief of imminent
    danger, that a reasonable prudent man of ordinary firmness and courage would have
    entertained the same belief [], or if his defense is based on his being in
    actual and imminent danger, that â€œthe circumstances were such as would warrant
    a man of ordinary prudence, firmness, and courage to strike the fatal blow in
    order to save himself from serious bodily harm, or losing his own life, (4)
    That he had no other probable means of avoiding the danger of losing his own
    life or sustaining serious bodily injury than to act as he did in the particular
    instance.Â  

Id. at 657-58, 244 S.E.2d at 505-06 (internal citations
  omitted).
At
  one time, self-defense was an affirmative defense in this State, and a
  defendant bore the burden of establishing it by a preponderance of the
  evidence.Â  State v. McDowell, 272 S.C. 203, 207, 249 S.E.2d 916, 918
  (1978).Â  However, current law requires the State to disprove self-defense, once
  raised by the defendant, beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  State v. Wiggins,
  330 S.C. 538, 544, 500 S.E.2d 489, 492-493 (1998).
When
  this Court reviews the denial of a motion for a directed verdict, it views the
  evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving party. Â State v. Long,
  325 S.C. 59, 62, 480 S.E.2d 62, 63 (1997).Â  When ruling on a motion for
  directed verdict, the trial judge is concerned with the existence of evidence,
  not its weight.Â  Id.Â  If there is any direct or substantial circumstantial
  evidence which reasonably tends to prove the guilt of the accused or from which
  guilt may be fairly and logically deduced, it is the trial courtâ€™s duty to
  submit the case to the jury.Â  Id.Â  In other words, if the State provided
  evidence sufficient to negate Dickeyâ€™s claim of self-defense, Dickeyâ€™s motion
  for directed verdict was properly denied.Â  
The State provided
  such evidence.Â  First, the State provided evidence which, if believed, tended
  to show Dickey was not without fault in bringing on the difficulty.Â  Any act of
  an accused that is reasonably calculated to produce the occasion amounts to
  bringing on the difficulty and bars the right to assert self-defense.Â  State
    v. Slater, 373 S.C. 66, 70, 644 S.E.2d 50, 52 (2007).Â  Additionally, the
  plea of self-defense is not available to one who kills another in mutual
  combat.Â  State v. Graham, 260 S.C. 449, 450, 196 S.E.2d 495, 495
  (1973).Â  In this case, a jury could have found that Dickeyâ€™s decision to exit
  the building and brandish his loaded gun, after the confrontation between him
  and Boot inside the apartment had all but ended, was an act that was reasonably
  calculated to provoke a new altercation with Boot, and that Dickey intended to
  engage in mutual combat.
Second,
  the State provided evidence that, if believed, tended to show Dickey had other
  probable means of avoiding the danger than to act as he did (i.e., that Dickey
  had a duty to retreat).Â  Under the Castle Doctrine, â€œone attacked, without
  fault on his own part, on his own premises, has the right in establishing his
  plea of self-defense, to claim immunity from the law of retreat, which
  ordinarily is an essential element of that defense.â€ State v. Hewitt,
  205 S.C. 207, 212, 31 S.E.2d 257, 258 (1944).Â  In this case, Dickey was not
  immune from the duty to retreat under the Castle Doctrine.Â  It is undisputed
  that Dickey was not inside the apartment building at the time he shot Boot, nor
  was he within the curtilage of the building.[2]Â 
  Rather, he was standing on a public sidewalk outside the apartment building.Â 
  He was, therefore, not immune as a matter of law under the Castle Doctrine.Â  
B.   Sufficiency of Jury
  Instructions on Self-Defense
A
  trial court has a duty to give a requested instruction that correctly states
  the law applicable to the issues and is supported by the evidence.Â  State v.
    Peer, 320 S.C. 546, 553, 466 S.E.2d 375, 380 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  To warrant
  reversal, a trial courtâ€™s refusal to give a requested jury charge must be both
  erroneous and prejudicial to the defendant.Â  State v. Hughey, 339 S.C.
  439, 450, 529 S.E.2d 721, 727 (2000).Â  If the instructions given to the jury
  afford the proper test for determining the issues, the failure to give one
  sideâ€™s requested instructions is not prejudicial.Â  Id. at 452, 529
  S.E.2d at 728.Â  

  i.      Curtilage

Dickey
  argues the trial court erred in refusing to charge the jury on curtilage.Â  We
  disagree.
A
  defendant has no duty to retreat when attacked in his home or at his place of
  business.Â  Wiggins, 330 S.C. at 548 n.15, 500 S.E.2d at 494 n.15.Â  This
  rule of immunity extends to the curtilage of the building as well.Â  Id.Â  Curtilage includes outbuildings, the yard around the dwelling, a garden of a
  dwelling, or the parking lot of a business. Id.Â  The common denominator
  between these places that are considered curtilage is they are places where the
  property owner alone has the right to be, to the exclusion of the general
  public.Â  See State v. McGee, 185 S.C. 184, 191, 193 S.E. 303, 306
  (1937) (holding duty to retreat applies on a public highway, â€œwhere all men have
  equal rightsâ€); State v. Rochester, 72 S.C. 194, 197, 51 S.E. 685, 686
  (1905) (â€œA man on his own premises has a greater right there than anybody
  else.â€).Â  They are not considered curtilage simply because they are close to
  the building or maintained by the owner.Â  State v. Boyd, 126 S.C. 300, 302,
  119 S.E. 839, 840 (1923) (holding one charged with assault and battery with
  intent to kill cannot defend on the ground that the Castle Doctrine extends to
  the middle of the street in front of the defendantâ€™s house).Â  
In
  this case, it is undisputed Dickey was on the doormat outside the front door to
  the Cornell Arms apartments at the time he shot Boot. The doormat was placed
  away from the threshold of the entrance to the building, on the public
  sidewalk.[3]Â 
  Although Dickey makes a colorable argument this portion of the sidewalk should
  be treated as curtilage of the apartment building,[4] the current law in this state does not include adjacent public sidewalks or
  public streets as curtilage such that the duty to retreat would be excused.Â  See McGee, 185 S.C. at 184, 193 S.E. at 306 (rejecting defendantâ€™s argument
  he had no duty to retreat in his car on a public street).Â  Other jurisdictions
  have similarly refused to hold there is no duty to retreat from a sidewalk in front
  of a business or residence.Â  See, e.g., Â State v. Menser, 382
  N.W.2d 18, 20 (Neb. 1986) (holding a sidewalk outside defendantâ€™s apartment
  house was not part of defendantâ€™s â€œdwellingâ€ within the meaning of law of
  self-defense); State v. Provoid, 110 N.J. Super. 547, 554, 266 A.2d 307,
  311 (1970) (noting the curtilage of oneâ€™s residence does not extend to a public
  thoroughfare running along the boundary of oneâ€™s property).Â  Unlike an
  outbuilding, yard or parking lot next to a building, the sidewalk is public
  land from which Dickey would not have had â€œthe right to eject his adversary.â€Â Â  Rochester, 72 S.C. at 203, 51 S.E. at 688.Â  Because the sidewalk was
  not within the curtilage of the apartment building, Dickey was not immune from
  the duty to retreat.Â  Therefore, the trial courtâ€™s refusal to instruct the jury
  on the law of curtilage was not error. 

  ii.      Defendantâ€™s Right to Act on
    Appearances

Dickey
  next argues the trial courtâ€™s instruction to the jury on the right to act on
  appearances was inadequate.Â  We disagree.
A
  jury charge is correct if, when the charge is read as a whole, it is
  substantially correct and adequately covers the law.Â  State v. Foust, 325
  S.C. 12, 16, 479 S.E.2d 50, 52 (1996).Â  Regarding the right to act on
  appearances, the Supreme Court has held:

  The
    test is not whether there was testimony of an intended attack but whether or
    not the appellant believed he was in imminent danger of death or serious bodily
    harm, and he is not required to show that such danger actually existed because
    he had a right to act upon such appearances as would cause a reasonable and
    prudent man of ordinary firmness and courage to entertain the same belief.

State v. Jackson, 227 S.C. 271, 279, 87 S.E.2d 681, 684 (1955).
In
  this case, the trial court instructed the jury on the second and third elements
  of self-defense as follows:

  In
    deciding whether the defendant was or believed that he was in imminent danger
    of death or serious bodily injury you should consider all of the facts and
    circumstances surrounding the offense including the physical condition and the
    characteristics of the defendant and the victim. . . [I]t does not have to
    appear that the defendant believed that he was actually in danger.Â  It is
    enough that the defendant believed that he was in imminent danger and a
    reasonably prudent person of ordinary firmness and courage would have had the
    same belief.Â  A defendant has the right to act on appearances even though the
    defendantâ€™s belief may have been mistaken.

Given the
  similarity between these two statements of the law, the trial court
  sufficiently instructed the jury on the right to act on appearances.

  
    iii.      Duty to Retreat
  

Although
  the trial court did instruct the jury on the duty to retreat, Dickey argues the
  charge was inadequate.Â  We disagree.
Despite
  the fact that Dickey was not within the curtilage at the time of the shooting,
  one may still satisfy the fourth prong of self-defense if he had no other
  probable means of avoiding the danger than to act as he did in the situation.Â  Hendrix,
  270 S.C. at 658, 244 S.E.2d at 506.Â  Here, Dickey presented evidence that, if
  believed, could have supported a finding that retreat would have increased the
  danger to him.Â  Had he retreated back into the apartmentâ€™s first set of heavy
  front doors, he would have encountered the locked interior doors to the lobby.
  If his assailants had then followed him in, he could have been trapped in an
  enclosed space, thereby increasing his risk of peril from what it would have
  been had he stood his ground outside.Â  Because this evidence, if believed,
  could have supported a finding of no duty to retreat, Dickey was entitled to a
  charge on the duty to retreat.Â  
The
  trial court instructed the jury on the duty to retreat as follows:

  Regardless
    of whether a defendant is on personal premises or business premises, . . . a
    defendant has no duty to retreat if by doing so the danger of being killed or
    suffering serious bodily injury would increase . . . [I]f both parties are
    where they have a right to be there is a duty to retreat unless retreating, in
    doing so the danger of being killed or suffering serious bodily injury would
    increase. 

Because
  this charge, when read as a whole, was substantially correct and adequately
  covers the law, it was a proper instruction on the duty to retreat.Â  Foust,
  325 S.C. at 16, 479 S.E.2d at 52.
C.   Voluntary Manslaughter
  Charge

  i.      Preservation of Error

The
  State argues the charge of voluntary manslaughter was not properly objected to
  by defense counsel and, therefore, the issue is not available for appellate
  review.Â  We disagree.
If a
  party fails to properly object, the party is procedurally barred from raising
  the issue on appeal.Â  State v. Pauling, 322 S.C. 95, 100, 470 S.E.2d
  106, 109 (1996).Â  A proper objection should be sufficiently specific to bring
  into focus the precise nature of the alleged error so that it can be reasonably
  understood by the trial court.Â  State v. Wigington, 375 S.C. 25, 35-36,
  649 S.E.2d 185, 190 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  
At
  the conclusion of the instructions to the jury, defense counsel stated his
  objection to the charge on voluntary manslaughter as, â€œWe do not think [the
  instruction on voluntary manslaughter] was appropriate with the facts and
  circumstances in the case.â€Â  The State argues this objection was not
  sufficiently specific to preserve the issue for appellate review.Â  While
  defense counsel could have made a more specific objection, the objection made
  it sufficiently clear to the trial court that defense counsel did not believe
  the evidence supported a charge of voluntary manslaughter.Â  Because the
  objection brought to the trial courtâ€™s attention the precise nature of the
  alleged error, the issue is properly preserved for our review.Â  

  
    ii.      Propriety of the Charge
  

Dickey
  argues the trial court erred in instructing the jury on voluntary manslaughter
  because no evidence was presented from which the jury could have reasonably
  concluded he acted â€œin the heat of passion.â€Â  We disagree.
The
  law to be charged must be determined from the evidence presented at trial. Â State
    v. Lee, 298 S.C. 362, 364, 380 S.E.2d 834, 835 (1989). Â In determining
  whether the evidence requires a charge on voluntary manslaughter, this Court
  must view the facts in the light most favorable to the defendant. Â State v.
    Byrd, 323 S.C. 319, 321, 474 S.E.2d 430, 431 (1996). Â For a court to refuse
  to charge a jury on manslaughter, there must be no evidence in the record
  tending to reduce the crime from murder to manslaughter. Â State v. Lowry,
  315 S.C. 396, 399, 434 S.E.2d 272, 274 (1993).
Voluntary
  manslaughter is the unlawful killing of a human being in sudden heat of passion
  upon sufficient legal provocation. Â State v. Kornahrens, 290 S.C. 281, 285-86,
  350 S.E.2d 180, 184 (1986). Â Evidence of acting in the heat of passion alone
  will not suffice to reduce murder to voluntary manslaughter. Â State v.
    Walker, 324 S.C. 257, 260, 478 S.E.2d 280, 281 (1996).Â  Rather, both heat
  of passion and sufficient legal provocation must be present at the time of the
  killing. Â State v. Tyson, 283 S.C. 375, 379, 323 S.E.2d 770, 772 (1984).
  Â To mitigate a felonious killing to manslaughter, the sudden heat of passion â€œmust
  be such as would naturally disturb the sway of reason, and render the mind of
  an ordinary person incapable of cool reflection, and produce what, according to
  human experience, may be called an uncontrollable impulse to do violence.â€ Â State
    v. Byrd, 323 S.C. 319, 322, 474 S.E.2d 430, 432 (1996) (internal quotations
  omitted).
Even
  assuming[5] adequate legal provocation by Boot, Dickey argues there was no evidence
  presented at trial from which the jury could have found he acted in the heat of
  passion at the time he shot Boot that would support the voluntary manslaughter
  charge.Â  Dickey points to witness testimony indicating he â€œremained calm,â€ â€œdid
  not ever touch Boot,â€ â€œdid not mouth off in return,â€ and â€œhad no prior bad
  feelings or ill will [towards Boot].â€ In contrast, the heat of passion is an uncontrollable
  impulse to do violence, which renders the mind incapable of cool reflection.Â  Byrd,
  323 S.C. at 322, 474 S.E.2d at 432.Â  Thus, Dickey argues he did in fact remain
  calm and in control, which necessarily means he was not acting in the heat of
  passion at the time of the shooting.Â  
In
  essence, Dickeyâ€™s position is that, in view of the evidence presented, the only
  emotion he was experiencing at the time he shot Boot was fear.Â 
  Dickey correctly points out that fear for oneâ€™s safety is a necessary prong of
  self-defense.Â  Hendrix, 270 S.C. at 657-58, 244 S.E.2d at 505-506.Â 
  Therefore, Dickey argues, if simply being afraid amounts to being in the heat
  of passion for purposes of voluntary manslaughter, the line separating it from
  self-defense would be blurred under such an interpretation.Â  To reconcile this,
  Dickey argues there must exist some legal difference between the type of
  reasonable fear that would support a self-defense claim on the one hand, and
  the type of fear that would support a verdict of voluntary manslaughter on the
  other.Â  Dickey argues the latter type is â€œfear that causes a person to lose
  control of himself temporarily,â€ and because the evidence did not support a
  finding of this latter type of fear, he was not acting in the heat of passion.Â 
  Thus, the charge was improper.Â  
However,
  it is well settled that self-defense and voluntary manslaughter are not
  mutually exclusive, and both issues should be submitted to the jury if
  supported by the evidence.Â  Wiggins, 330 S.C. at 549 n.18, 500 S.E.2d at
  495 n.18; State v. Nichols, 325 S.C. 111, 118, 481 S.E.2d 118, 122
  (1997); State v. Gilliam, 296 S.C. 395, 396, 373 S.E.2d 596, 597
  (1988).Â  The rationale for this rule is that the jury may fail to find all the
  elements for self-defense but could find sufficient legal provocation and heat
  of passion to conclude the defendant was guilty of voluntary manslaughter.Â  Gilliam,
  296 S.C. at 396-97, 373 S.E.2d at 597.Â  Furthermore, contrary to Dickeyâ€™s
  argument, fear can constitute a basis for heat of passion to support voluntary
  manslaughter. See Wiggins, 330 S.C. at 549, 500 S.E.2d at 495 (holding
  when evidence showed appellant was in a heated argument with the victim and was
  afraid for his life because victim physically threatened him, such evidence, if
  believed, would tend to show appellant acted in sudden heat of passion).
In
  this case, ample evidence was introduced that would support a finding of heat
  of passion.Â  Dickey and Boot engaged in a heated argument before the shooting
  and Boot verbally threatened Dickey. Evidence of arguments and physical threats
  prior to a homicide can support a charge of manslaughter.Â  See Lowry,
  315 S.C. at 399, 434 S.E.2d at 274 (holding it was an error for trial court to
  refuse to charge on manslaughter when there was testimony which, if believed,
  tended to show that the decedent and the defendant were in a heated argument
  and that the decedent was about to initiate a physical encounter when the shooting
  occurred).Â  Dickey also testified Boot came at him in a threatening manner,
  reaching under his shirt for what could have been a weapon, and said to Dickey,
  â€œF___ it, letâ€™s do it.â€Â  Taken together, these could support a finding that
  Dickey was in the heat of passion.Â  See Gilliam, 296 S.C. at 397,
  373 S.E.2d at 597 (â€œAppellantâ€™s testimony that the victim threatened him and
  then fired at him would support a finding of sufficient legal provocation and
  heat of passion.â€).Â  
D.   Trial Judgeâ€™s
  â€œIllustrationâ€ of Voluntary Manslaughter
Dickey
  argues the trial courtâ€™s illustration during his instructions to the jury on
  voluntary manslaughter was an improper comment on the facts of the case.Â  We
  disagree.
Article
  V, Â§ 21 of the South Carolina Constitution states: â€œJudges shall not charge
  juries in respect to matters of fact, but shall declare the law.â€Â  South Carolina law dictates a trial judge should refrain from any comment that tends to
  indicate to the jury his opinion on the credibility of witnesses, the weight of
  the evidence, or the guilt of the accused.Â  State v. Jackson, 297 S.C.
  523, 526, 377 S.E.2d 570, 572 (1989).Â  However, jury instructions must be
  considered in their entirety and, if in their entirety are free from error, any
  potentially misleading portions do not constitute reversible error.Â  Id.Â  
â€œOftentimes
  juries can be made to understand the law of the case easier if they are given
  helpful illustrations.â€ Â State v. Quick, 141 S.C. 442, 447, 140 S.E. 97,
  99 (1927). Â A charge that states the legal conclusions that would result from
  the establishment of certain facts is not necessarily an improper charge on the
  facts, nor a mandate to the jury to assume the truth of the facts as stated.Â  Williams
    v. Se. Life Ins. Co.Â  197 S.C. 171, 177, 14 S.E.2d 895, 897 (1941).Â  The
  test is how a reasonable juror would have understood the charge. Â Sheppard
    v. State, 357 S.C. 646, 664, 594 S.E.2d 462, 472 (2004).
Here,
  it is unlikely that a reasonable juror would have singled out the illustration
  portion of the charge and interpreted it as the courtâ€™s opinion on the facts of
  this case or as an instruction on the weight to be given to the evidence.Â 
  First, the jury was reminded numerous times of its role as arbiter of the facts.
  Second, the trial court prefaced its illustration by making clear it was just
  an illustration. Third, the trial courtâ€™s illustration took on the form: â€œIf X,
  Y and Z occur, that constitutes manslaughter.â€Â  He did not say, â€œX, Y and Z
  occurred.â€Â  See, e.g., State v. Smith, 288 S.C. 329, 330-31, 342
  S.E.2d. 600, 601 (1986) (holding judgeâ€™s instruction, â€œIf the State proves [elements
  one through four], then the results of the test can be admitted into evidence
  and the jury to consider. You have heard such evidenceâ€ was error
  because a reasonable juror could have construed that the trial judge felt the
  State had met its burden of proof on the required elements) (emphasis added).Â 
  In this case, the trial courtâ€™s illustration was an explanation, not commentary.Â 
  Taken as a whole, the instructions were not erroneous.
E.   Retroactive Application of
  â€œStand Your Groundâ€ Law
Dickey
  argues that the trial court should have applied the recently enacted Protection
  of Persons and Property Act (the Act) to his case.Â  The Act has an effective
  date of June 9, 2006, and Dickey was charged with murder on April 29, 2004, and
  convicted of manslaughter on September 15, 2006.

  
    i.      Preservation of Error
  

The
  State argues Dickey did not properly assert this argument to the trial court,
  and so it is not preserved for appellate review.Â  We disagree.
An
  issue not presented to the trial court is not preserved for appellate review.Â  State
    v. Johnson,Â  324 S.C. 38, 41, 476 S.E.2d 681, 682 (1996).Â  See also State v. Tucker, 319 S.C. 425, 427-28, 462 S.E.2d 264, 264-65 (1995)
  (holding when defendant failed to object to a jury charge, issue is not
  preserved for consideration on appeal); State v. Stone, 285 S.C. 386,
  387, 330 S.E.2d 286, 287 (1985) (holding defendantâ€™s failure to object to
  charge as given, or to request an additional charge when the opportunity to do
  so has been afforded, waived the right to complain on appeal); State v. Rogers,
  361 S.C. 178, 183, 603 S.E.2d 910, 912-13 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding that to
  preserve an issue for appellate review, the issue must have been raised to and
  ruled upon by the trial court, raised by the appellant, raised in a timely
  manner, and raised to the trial court with sufficient specificity).Â  
Defense
  counsel in this case argued before the trial court, on the record, that the
  trial court should apply the Act to this case.Â  Thereafter, the trial court
  heard opposing argument from the State on this same issue.Â  After hearing from
  both parties on the issue, the trial court ruled on the issue, stating: â€œI think
  it was clearly the intent of the legislature, that . . . this [A]ct does not
  apply to pending criminal prosecution.Â  For that reason that is the courtâ€™s
  ruling.â€ Â The issue was timely raised on the record and ruled upon by the trial
  court and is, therefore, preserved for review.

  
    ii.      Retroactive Application
  

Dickey
  argues the trial court erred in refusing to apply the Act to this case.Â  We
  disagree.
The
  retrospective operation of a statute is not favored by the courts, and statutes
  are presumed to be prospective in effect.Â  State v. Davis, 309 S.C. 326,
  334, 422 S.E.2d 133, 139 (1992), overruled on other grounds by Brightman
    v. State, 336 S.C. 348, 352 n.2, 520 S.E.2d 614, 616 n.2 (1999).Â  The
  Supreme Court has recognized that â€œ[a] statute is not to be applied
  retroactively unless that result is so clearly compelled as to leave no room
  for doubt.â€Â  Am. Nat. Fire Ins. Co. v. Smith Grading & Paving, 317
  S.C. 445, 449, 454 S.E.2d 897, 899 (1995).Â  The exception to this rule of
  prospective operation is where the statute is remedial or procedural in nature.Â  Hercules, Inc. v. S.C. Tax Commâ€™n, 274 S.C. 137, 143, 262 S.E.2d 45, 48
  (1980).
Dickey
  argues the Act should be applied retroactively because it is procedural in
  nature. We disagree.Â  
The
  Act, by codifying the common law Castle Doctrine, creates substantive rights
  for citizens.Â  The Act â€œextends the [Castle] doctrine to include an occupied
  vehicle and the personâ€™s place of business.â€[6]Â 
  The Act also gives citizens the right â€œto protect themselves, their families
  and others from intruders and attackers without fear of prosecution or civil
  action.â€[7]Â 
  Therefore, because the rights are substantive, the Act will only operate
  retroactively if there is a clear indication from the legislature that this was
  intended.Â  Am. Nat. Fire, 317 S.C. at 449, 454 S.E.2d at 899.Â  There is
  no such indication in the Act.Â  The Act specifically states it was not
  effective until approved by the Governor, which occurred on June 9, 2006.Â  2006
  S.C. Act No. 379 Â§ 6.Â  This effective date was over two years after the
  shooting at the Cornell Arms Apartments.Â  Additionally, section 4 of the Act
  provides the following savings clause:

  The
    repeal or amendment by this act of any law, whether temporary or permanent,
    civil or criminal, does not affect pending actions, rights, duties, or
    liabilities founded thereon, or alter, discharge, release or extinguish any
    penalty, forfeiture, or liability incurred under the repealed or amended law,
    unless the repealed or amended provision shall so expressly provide.Â  After the
    effective date of this act, all laws repealed or amended by this act must be
    taken and treated as remaining in full force and effect for the purpose of
    sustaining any pending or vested right, civil action, special proceeding,
    criminal prosecution, or appeal existing as of the effective date of this act,
    and for the enforcement of rights, duties, penalties and forfeitures, and
    liabilities as they stood under the repealed or amended laws. 

Here,
  the Legislature clearly manifested its intent that the Act be applied
  prospectively.Â  As such, the fact that Dickeyâ€™s prosecution was pending before
  the effective date of the Act precludes the application of the Act to this
  case.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the
  trial courtâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON and
  KONDUROS, JJ., concur.


[1] The record
  indicates that the ladies and their neighbors were in the practice of tossing
  water balloons at each otherâ€™s apartments as part of an ongoing â€œjoke.â€ 
[2] A discussion of
  curtilage follows.
[3] At oral argument,
  counsel for Dickey argued the front mat was located in an â€œindentation,â€ away
  from the sidewalk, such that the front edge of the doormat was flush with the
  front of the building and therefore not on the sidewalk.Â  However, photos taken
  at the crime scene do not corroborate this.
[4] Dickey argues
  the shooting occurred on the curtilage of the apartment building because the
  sidewalk was covered by the buildingâ€™s awning; Dickey was on the front door mat
  when the shooting occurred; Cornell Arms owned both the doormat and the awning;
  and Cornell Arms maintained the flower beds and benches on the sidewalk.
[5] In his brief,
  Appellant has phrased his argument as: â€œ[M]anslaughter is not a valid verdict
  where Dickey was not acting in the heat of passion.â€Â  He does not dispute the
  finding of adequate legal provocation.Â  His argument on appeal is therefore
  limited to whether Dickey was in the heat of passion.Â  An issue that is not
  argued in the brief is deemed abandoned and precludes consideration on appeal.Â 
  Rule 208(b)(1)(D), SCACR; Jinks v. Richland County, 355 S.C. 341, 344
  n.3, 585 S.E.2d 281, 283 n.3 (2003).
[6] S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§ 16-11-420(A) (2006).
[7] S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§ 16-11-420(B) (2006).

title: Feldman v. Feldman
description: In this family law action Husband appeals the family court's decision not to terminate his obligation to pay Wife alimony.  Wife appeals the family court's decision not to award her attorney's fees.  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Donald R.
          Feldman, Appellant/Respondent,
        v.
        Francine
          Feldman, Respondent/Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Robert S. Armstrong, Family Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4452
  Heard October 8, 2008 â€“ Filed October 29,
2008

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        J. Mark Taylor, of West Columbia and Peggy McMillan Infinger, of Charleston, for Appellant/Respondent.
        Beth Ann Gilleland, of Bluffton, for Respondent/Appellant.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS J.:Â  In
  this family law action, Donald Feldman (Husband) appeals the family courtâ€™s
  decision not to terminate his obligation to pay Francine Feldmanâ€™s (Wife)
  alimony.Â  Wife appeals the family courtâ€™s decision not to award her attorneyâ€™s
  fees.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand. 
FACTS
Husband and Wife were divorced in June 2000.Â  Husband was required
  to pay Wife permanent periodic alimony in the amount of $4,500 per month.Â  In
  May 2004, Husbandâ€™s obligation was reduced to $4,000 per month.Â  In September
  2005, Husband brought an action to have his alimony obligation terminated
  pursuant to the continued cohabitation provision of section 20-3-130(B)(1) of
  the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2007), claiming Wife and Frank Watson
  (Boyfriend) had engaged in a romantic relationship and resided together for a
  period of ninety or more consecutive days.Â  Wife and Boyfriend did not deny the
  romantic relationship, but both disputed the claim of cohabitation.Â  Â 
Wife and Boyfriend became acquainted in the latter part of 2002.Â 
  Wife characterized the nature of their relationship at that time as
  acquaintances.Â  However, the two became romantically involved in August 2003.Â 
  In October 2003, Wife invested approximately $50,000 in Boyfriendâ€™s business.[1]Â  As security for her investment Wife
  received fifty percent of the stocks in this business.Â  Subsequently, Wife
  became the sole owner of Decorative Concrete and Design as a result of
  additional investments.Â  
Husband became suspicious of the relationship between Boyfriend
  and Wife and hired Randy Caulder (Caulder), a private investigator, in April
  2005 to investigate the matter.Â  Consequently, Caulder began surveillance of
  Wifeâ€™s condominium.Â  The surveillance entailed Caulder periodically checking to
  see what vehicles were at Wifeâ€™s residence in the evenings and mornings.Â  Wifeâ€™s
  condominium complex had numbered parking slots corresponding to each
  condominium.Â  Wife, who resided in condominium number 302, was assigned two
  parking slots enumerated as 302 and 302 visitor.Â  
Caulder testified that on multiple occasions he observed a BMW and
  a silver Chevrolet pickup in parking spaces 302 and 302 visitor, respectively.Â 
  According to Caulder, the BMW belonged to Wife and the pickup belonged to
  Boyfriend.Â  Caulder explained that in the evening Wife would park the BMW in
  spot 302 and enter her condominium.Â  Shortly thereafter, Boyfriend would park
  his pickup in spot 302 visitor and go into Wifeâ€™s condominium.Â  
On a few occasions, Caulder arrived early in the morning at the
  condominium complex and observed Boyfriend exiting Wifeâ€™s condominium, get in
  his pickup and leave.Â  Thus, Caulder could at least place Boyfriendâ€™s vehicle
  at Wifeâ€™s residence late at night and early in the morning.Â  Additionally,
  Caulder interacted with Boyfriend at Wifeâ€™s condominium on two occasions.Â  
In the first instance, Caulder was commissioned by a law firm to
  serve papers on Boyfriend.Â  As a result, Caulder went to Wifeâ€™s condominium and
  found Boyfriend there.Â  The second time, Caulder was instructed to serve papers
  on Wife.Â  Once again, Caulder arrived at Wifeâ€™s condominium and found Boyfriend
  there.Â  Caulder left the papers with Boyfriend along with instructions that the
  papers were to be given to Wife when she arrived home.Â  
Upon hearing all the evidence, the family court found Husband had
  failed to carry his burden of proof to show Wife and Boyfriend engaged in
  continued cohabitation for ninety or more consecutive days pursuant to section 20-3-130(B)(1).Â 
  Based on this, the family court did not terminate Husbandâ€™s obligation to pay
  Wife alimony.Â  The family court further denied Wifeâ€™s request for
  attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Both parties appeal.
STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
In
  appeals from the family court, this Court may find facts in accordance with its
  own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Nasser-Moghaddassi v.
    Moghaddassi, 364 S.C. 182, 189-90, 612 S.E.2d 707, 711 (Ct. App.
  2005).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require this Court to
  disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Id.Â  Nor must we ignore the fact
  that the family court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better
  position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their
  testimony.Â  Id.Â  However, our broad scope of review does not relieve the
  appellant of the burden of convincing this Court that the family court
  committed error.Â  Id. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Husbandâ€™s appeal 
Husband argues the family court erred in failing to find
  Wife engaged in continued cohabitation with Boyfriend and, therefore, erred in
  not terminating alimony.Â  Husband also contends the family courtâ€™s final ruling
  is contradicted by its ruling at the directed verdict stage.Â  We disagree.
Section
  20-3-130(B)(1) allows for the termination of alimony upon â€œthe remarriage or
  continued cohabitation of the supported spouse . . . .â€Â  The statute states:

  For
    purposes of this subsection and unless otherwise agreed to in writing by the
    parties, â€œcontinued cohabitationâ€ means the supported spouse resides with
    another person in a romantic relationship for a period of ninety or more
    consecutive days.Â  The court may determine that a continued cohabitation exists
    if there is evidence that the supported spouse resides with another person in a
    romantic relationship for periods of less than ninety days and the two
    periodically separate in order to circumvent the ninety-day requirement.Â  

Â§
  20-3-130(B).Â  
The continued
  cohabitation requirement necessitates the supported spouse reside with another
  person for ninety or more consecutive days.Â  Id.Â  The term â€œreside,â€ as
  used in this context, has recently been explained to mean that â€œthe supported
  spouse live under the same roof as the person with whom they are romantically
  involved for at least ninety consecutive days.â€Â  Semken v. Semken, 379
  S.C. 71, 76, 664 S.E.2d 493, 496 (Ct. App. 2008) (citing Strickland v. Strickland,
  375 S.C. 76, 89, 650 S.E.2d 465, 472 (2007)).Â  
In
  the case at hand, Husband relies heavily on the testimony of Caulder in arguing
  the family courtâ€™s finding that Wife and Boyfriend did not engage in continued
  cohabitation should be reversed.Â  Caulder was hired to perform surveillance on
  Wifeâ€™s residence on April 2005.Â  As noted above, Caulder testified that
  Boyfriend drove a Chevrolet pickup truck.Â  Caulder performed surveillance on
  Wifeâ€™s residence only twenty-one times.Â  
Of
  these days, ten were before June 13, 2005.Â  However, a bill of sale produced at
  trial showed Boyfriend purchased the pickup on June 13, 2005.Â  This negated any
  possibility of Caulder observing Boyfriend driving, entering, or exiting the
  pickup prior to June 13, 2005.Â  Such evidence falls well short of the ninety
  day requirement mandated by section 20-3-130(B)(1).Â  
Caulder admitted he did not know whether Wife and Boyfriend lived
  together.Â  Caulder also admitted he could not state if Boyfriend ever stayed
  the night at Wifeâ€™s condominium.Â  Additionally, Caulder conceded he did not
  know whether Boyfriend and Wife had stayed together for ninety or more days.Â  Moreover, testimony produced at trial supported the
  conclusion that Husband failed to carry his burden of proof.
Both
  Boyfriend and Wife freely admitted the romantic nature of their relationship,
  but both denied that Boyfriend had stayed with Wife for ninety or more days.Â  Such assertions may appear to be self-serving, but they were
  corroborated by testimony from individuals who visited or stayed with Wife in
  her residence.Â Â  
For example, Wifeâ€™s friend Marian Nalven, who characterized her
  relationship with Wife as that of mother and daughter, testified that Wife
  lived alone.Â  Wifeâ€™s friend Kathy Nalven, who characterized her relationship with
  Wife as that of sisters, also stated that Wife lived alone.Â  Karin Gutierrez,
  who has known Wife all her life, testified that Wife did not live with anyone.
  Wifeâ€™s former employee Lana Brantley stated that Wife lived alone.Â  Wifeâ€™s next
  door neighbor of two years testified Wife lived alone.Â  Another of Wifeâ€™s
  friends, Janice Malafronte, stated Wife was the sole occupant of her
  condominium.Â  Wife and Husbandâ€™s son, Paul Feldman, who characterized his
  relationship with his mother as excellent, testified Wife stayed alone. 
Based on the foregoing, the family court did not err in
  determining Husband failed to carry his burden of proof to show Wife and
  Boyfriend engaged in continued cohabitation for ninety or more consecutive days
  pursuant to section 20-3-130(B)(1).Â  See Nasser-Moghaddassi, 364 S.C. at
  190-91, 612 S.E.2d at 711 (noting the
  family court judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position
  to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony
  and the appellant bears the burden of convincing this Court that the family
  court committed error).
Husband
  also maintains the family courtâ€™s decision not to terminate alimony should be
  reversed because Wifeâ€™s and Boyfriendâ€™s relationship was tantamount to
  marriage.Â  Husbandâ€™s complaint listed two grounds for termination of alimony.Â 
  First, pursuant to section 20-3-170 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2007) a
  family court may terminate an award of alimony when the circumstances of the
  parties have changed.Â  Husband argued the change in circumstances is that Wife
  and Boyfriendâ€™s relationship is tantamount to marriage.Â  Second, Husband relied
  on the continued cohabitation for ninety or more
  consecutive days pursuant to section 20-3-130(B)(1) to terminate alimony.Â  In
  its order, the family court stated, â€œThe [Husband] did not prove . . . [Wife]
  is co-habitating with [Boyfriend] as defined in [section 20-3-130] nor did . .
  . [Husband] provide any proof . . . [Wife] and [Boyfriend] were attempting to
  circumvent the ninety (90) day rule as contemplated by [section 20-3-130] . . .
  .â€ The family court never ruled on whether Wifeâ€™s and Boyfriendâ€™s relationship
  was tantamount to marriage.Â  In South Carolina for an issue to be preserved for
  appellate review it must be raised to and ruled upon by the lower court. Wilder Corp. v. Wilke,
  330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (holding for an issue to be preserved for appeal it must have been raised to and ruled upon by the lower court).Â  Thus, this issue is not preserved
  for our review.Â  
Additionally, South Carolina case law clearly states â€œ[a] party must file [a rule 59(e)] motion
  when an issue or argument has been raised, but not ruled on, in order to
  preserve it for appellate review.â€Â  Elam v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp.,
  361 S.C. 9, 24, 602 S.E.2d 772, 780 (2004) (emphasis in original).Â  In the
  present case Husband failed to make a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion when the family
  court did not rule on whether Boyfriendâ€™s and Wifeâ€™s relationship
  was tantamount to marriage.Â  Consequently, this issue is not preserved for
  review.Â  Id.
Husband
  also argues the family courtâ€™s final ruling is contradicted by its ruling at
  the directed verdict stage.Â  At the conclusion of Husbandâ€™s case-in-chief, Wife
  made a motion for a directed verdict.Â  The family court denied this motion.Â  In
  so doing, the family court held there was some evidence of cohabitation,
  presumably based on the testimony of Caulder.Â  In its final ruling, the family
  court held Husband failed to provide â€œany proofâ€ that Wife and Boyfriend were
  attempting to circumvent the ninety day requirement of section 20-3-130.Â 
  Husband maintains these two rulings are contradictory.Â Â  Because Husband fails
  to cite authority in support of his argument, we consider the argument
  abandoned.Â  Glasscock, Inc. v. U.S. Fid. & Guar. Co., 348 S.C. 76, 81, 557 S.E.2d 689, 691
  (Ct. App. 2001) (holding statements made without supporting authority are
  deemed abandoned on appeal and are not presented for review).
II. Wifeâ€™s Appeal 
Wife
  argues the family court erred in failing to award her attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  As a
  result of this litigation, Wife has incurred attorneyâ€™s fees in the amount of
  $22,038.05.Â  We agree.
The
  family court has discretion in deciding whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, and
  its decision will not be overturned absent an abuse of discretion. Â Donahue
    v. Donahue, 299 S.C. 353, 365, 384 S.E.2d 741, 748 (1989).Â  An abuse of discretion
  occurs when the decision is controlled by an error of law or is based on
  factual findings that are without evidentiary support.Â  Degenhart v. Burriss, 360 S.C. 497, 500, 602 S.E.2d 96,
  97 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
In
  deciding whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the family court should consider the
  following: (1) each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fee; (2) the
  beneficial results obtained by the attorney; (3) the partiesâ€™ respective
  financial conditions; and (4) the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of
  living. Â E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).Â  If an
  award of attorneyâ€™s fees is appropriate, the reasonableness of the fees should
  be determined according to: (1)
    the nature, extent, and difficulty of the case; (2) the time necessarily
    devoted to the case; (3) the professional standing of counsel; (4) the
    contingency of compensation; (5) the beneficial results obtained; and (6)
  the customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403
  S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).
In adjudicating Wifeâ€™s claim for attorneyâ€™s fees, the
  family court stated, â€œUnder the fact enunciated in Glasscock v. Glasscock . . . each party should be responsible for their own attorney fees and costs as
  a result of this litigation.â€Â  The family court failed to make any findings
  regarding whether Wife was entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees under the factors set
  out in E.D.M. v. T.A.M.Â  Rather, the family
    court considered the Glasscock factors which deal with determining the reasonableness
    of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Therefore, the issue of whether Wife is entitled to
    attorneyâ€™s fees is remanded back to the family court so that it may consider
    the factors set out in E.D.M. v. T.A.M.Â  If the family court determines
    Wife is entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees, it should then consider the reasonableness
    of such fees based on the Glasscock factors. 
The family court should comply with Rule
  26(a), SCRFC, which states, â€œAn order or judgment pursuant to an adjudication in a domestic
  relations case shall set forth the specific findings of fact and conclusions of
  law to support the courtâ€™s decision.â€Â  Holcombe v. Hardee, 304 S.C. 522,
  524, 405 S.E.2d 821, 822 (1991) (reversing and remanding a case back to the
  family court because the family courtâ€™s order failed to comply with Rule 26(a),
  SCRFC, in that the family court listed the factors to be considered for child
  support and stated it had considered them but failed to make findings of facts
  concerning those factors).
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  the family courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED
  IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
ANDERSON
  and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.
  

[1] Boyfriendâ€™s business is entitled Decorative Concrete
  and Design Incorporated, which specializes in concrete dÃ©cor.Â Â

description: Father appeals the family courtâ€™s admission of various hearsay statements of Child during a Department of Social Services intervention case.  We reverse and remand for a new trial.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        South Carolina Department
          of Social Services, Respondent,
        v.
        Lisa C., Frank C., Frank
          C., Sr., and Linda C.,    
        In the Interest of Minor
          Child I and Minor Child II,
        Of Whom Frank
          C. is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â Robert E. Guess, Family Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4453
  Heard September 16, 2008 â€“ Filed October
30, 2008

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        D.
          Bradley Jordan, of Rock Hill; and John D. Elliott, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        David
          Simpson, of York, for Respondent.
      
    
  

KONDUROS,
  J.:Â  Father appeals the family courtâ€™s admission of various
    hearsay statements of Child during a Department of Social Services (DSS)
    intervention case.Â  We reverse and remand for a new trial. [1]
FACTS
Mother and Father
  are parents of twin girls born in 1999.Â  DSS filed an intervention action in
  2006 pursuant to section 20-7-738 of the South Carolina Code contending Father
  posed a threat of abuse or neglect to Children.Â  However, the trial focused
  primarily on allegations of sexual abuse by Father as to one Child. Â Mother and
  Father had been living separate and apart for approximately three years at the
  time of trial.Â  
Child testified at
  trial, but did not reveal any sexual abuse by Father at that time.Â  Father
  elected not to cross-examine Child.Â  Dr. Deborah Reyes testified on behalf of DSS.Â 
  Dr. Reyes testified she was the Director of Clinical Services for the Dickerson Center for Children, a non-profit child advocacy center.Â  Her qualifications
  included a Masterâ€™s degree and Ph.D. in clinical psychology as well as numerous
  courses in forensic interviewing.Â  She became licensed by the state of South Carolina the Friday prior to the trial of this case.Â  Dr. Reyes testified she
  conducted a forensic interview with Child after another Dickerson Center staff person reported a â€œproblematic non-disclosure.â€[2]Â  
Dr.
  Reyes testified Child made the following disclosures in response to
  questioning:

  At this
    point, I asked her if anyone had touched her private.Â  She said yes.Â  When I
    asked her to tell me about that, she said, â€œMy daddy.â€Â  I asked her what did
    her daddy do and then she said . . . â€œthat he put a card on there from the cow
    place[3] and that daddy use to bite us on the butt.â€Â  

Dr.
  Reyes further testified Child told her Father had touched her with the card â€œon
  the inside and that it felt bad on her private part.â€Â  Finally, Dr. Reyes
  indicated Child said Father had touched her â€œhinnyâ€ many times, and â€œDaddy put
  a car inside.â€Â  
Father objected to Dr.
  Reyesâ€™ testifying about Childâ€™s hearsay statements during the interview.Â  However,
  the family court allowed the statements relying on section 19-1-180 of the South
  Carolina Code, which makes hearsay statements by children in abuse and neglect
  cases admissible under certain circumstances.
Mother also
  testified concerning a prior hearsay statement by Child regarding alleged
  sexual abuse.Â  Mother stated Child told her Father â€œhad put his mouth on her
  private.â€Â  Father objected to the admission of this testimony, but the family
  court determined section 19-1-180(G) did not prohibit the admission of such
  testimony as long as the hearsay statement was made prior to Mother and Fatherâ€™s
  separation.
Detective Cathryn Bell of the Chester County Sheriffâ€™s Office testified Child told her â€œDaddy rolled up a
  cow place card, and he put it in my hoochie.â€Â  Detective Bell understood Childâ€™s
  reference to â€œhoochieâ€ to mean Childâ€™s vaginal area.Â  Detective Bell further testified, over Fatherâ€™s objection, there was probable cause to leave the
  criminal case against Father open.Â  
Dr. Patricia Tonkawitz,
  Childâ€™s pediatrician, conducted a physical exam of Child, which yielded normal
  findings.Â  Over Fatherâ€™s objection, Dr. Tonkawitz also testified about a
  portion of her report in which she indicated Motherâ€™s history regarding Child was
  â€œconvincing.â€
The
  family court determined Children faced a threat of harm of sexual abuse from
  Father and ordered visitation between Father and Children be supervised by
  Fatherâ€™s parents.Â  Furthermore, the court ordered Father to attend parenting
  classes and undergo mental health and sexual predator evaluations.Â  The case
  was set for further review in three months.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn appeals from the family court, the appellate court has the
  authority to correct errors of law and to find facts in accordance
  with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Â However, this broad scope
  of review does not require this court to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.â€Â  Mr. T v. Ms. T, 378
  S.C. 127, 131-32, 662 S.E.2d 413, 415 (Ct. App. 2008) (citations omitted), cert.
    pending.Â  â€œThe admission or exclusion of evidence is left to the sound
  discretion of the trial court, and the courtâ€™s decision will not be reversed
  absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  State v. Morris, 376 S.C. 189, 205, 656 S.E.2d 359, 368 (2008).Â  The
  trial court abuses its discretion when that decision is based upon an error of
  law or upon factual findings that are without evidentiary support.Â  Id. at 206, 656 S.E.2d at 368.
LAW/ANALYSIS[4]
This appeal concerns the admission of testimonial evidence
  involving both matters of law and matters that were within the discretion of the
  family court judge.Â  The controlling statute at issue is section 19-1-180 of
  the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2007).Â  The statute considers how the court will
  address otherwise inadmissible out-of-court statements by children under twelve
  in a family court proceeding regarding allegations of abuse and neglect.

  An out-of-court
    statement may be admitted . . . if:  
  
    (1) the child testifies at the proceeding
      or testifies by means of videotaped deposition or closed-circuit television,
      and at the time of the testimony the child is subject to cross-examination about
      the statement or:
    (2)(a) the child
      is found by the court to be unavailable to testify on any of these grounds:
    
      (i) the childâ€™s death;
      (ii) the childâ€™s physical or mental
        disability;
      (iii) the existence of a privilege
        involving the child;
      (iv) the childâ€™s incompetency, including
        the childâ€™s inability to communicate about the offense because of fear;
      (v) substantial likelihood that the child
        would suffer severe emotional trauma from testifying at the proceeding or by
        means of videotaped deposition or closed-circuit television; and
    
    (b) the childâ€™s out-of-court statement is
      shown to possess particularized guarantees of trustworthiness.
  

Â§ 19-1-180(B). The statute also attempts to protect against the
  admission of a childâ€™s accusations that could be motivated by the malice of one
  parent for the other.

  If
    the parents of the child are separated or divorced, the hearsay statement shall
    be inadmissible if (1) one of the parents is the alleged perpetrator of the alleged
    abuse or neglect and (2) the allegation was made after the parties separated or
    divorced. Notwithstanding this subsection, a statement alleging abuse or
    neglect made by a child to a law enforcement official, an officer of the court,
    a licensed family counselor or therapist, a physician or other health care
    provider, a teacher, a school counselor, a Department of Social Services staff
    member, or to a child care worker in a regulated child care facility is
    admissible under this section.

Â§ 19-1-180(G).
I. Objections to
  TestimonyÂ  
A. Dr.
  Reyesâ€™ Testimony
Father
  contends Dr. Reyesâ€™ testimony regarding Childâ€™s statements was not admissible
  under this statute, because Childâ€™s testimony was not found to be trustworthy
  by the family court.Â  We disagree. Â The admission of Dr. Reyesâ€™ testimony
  appears to be proper under section
  19-1-180(B)(1).Â  Child testified at trial
  and was subject to cross-examination.Â  Therefore, pursuant to section 19-1-180(B)(1), there was no requirement Child be found
  unavailable or the family court conduct an analysis of the trustworthiness of
  those statements.Â  See Charleston County Depâ€™t of Soc.
    Servs. v. Father, Stepmother & Mother, 317 S.C. 283, 289, 454 S.E.2d
  307, 310 (1995) (approving admission of childâ€™s hearsay statements in absence
  of trustworthiness analysis when child testified at trial).
Father
  further argues if Dr. Reyesâ€™ testimony regarding Childâ€™s statements was
  admissible under part (B) of the statute, it was excluded under part (G) of the
  statute because she was not a licensed family counselor or therapist at the
  time she interviewed Child.Â  We agree.Â  The family court considered this
  argument and determined Dr. Reyes fell with the ambit of persons covered by the
  statute as either a health care provider or a therapist.Â  Furthermore, the
  family court relied upon Dr. Reyesâ€™ experience and qualifications and her
  subsequent licensure to establish the credibility and reliability of her
  testimony.Â  
â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and
  effectuate the intent of the legislature.â€Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C.
  79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000).Â  Here, the
  family court concluded the term therapist was not necessarily modified by
  licensed in the statute.Â  We disagree with this finding. Â The intent of the overall statute is to aid in the
  protection of children from abuse and neglect by permitting the introduction of
  their hearsay statements.Â  However, the purpose of part (G) is to protect a
  parent from potentially false accusations instigated by the other parent as
  part of a contentious divorce or custody battle. Â To conclude the
  legislature intended the testimony of unlicensed therapists to be admitted is
  inconsistent with the intent to limit the admission of hearsay statements.Â  
Additionally,
  finding Dr. Reyes fell within the category of healthcare providers is again
  inconsistent with the statute.Â  The legislature placed a licensure requirement
  on mental health professionals that cannot be disregarded by categorizing Dr.
  Reyes as both a therapist and a healthcare provider.Â  While mental health is
  undoubtedly part of a childâ€™s overall well-being, the legislature separated the
  groups in the statute thereby making a distinction between the groups that we
  cannot ignore.
Even
  though we disagree with the family courtâ€™s analysis of this issue, we may still
  affirm the admission of Childâ€™s statements through Dr. Reyes if there is
  another basis in the record for doing so.Â  See Rule 220(c), SCACR.Â  At
  trial, DSS also contended Dr. Reyesâ€™ testimony was admissible because she was
  licensed at the time of trial.Â  We disagree.
If a
  statuteâ€™s language is plain, unambiguous, and conveys a clear and definite
  meaning, rules of statutory interpretation are not necessary, and the court has
  no right to look for or impose another meaning.Â  Hodges, 341 S.C. at 85, 533 S.E.2d at 581.Â  In this
  case, part (G) makes admissible hearsay statements â€œmade by a child to . . . a licensed family counselor or therapist.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  The plain language of the statute indicates
  licensure is required at the time the statement by the child is made.Â  The
  record is clear Dr. Reyes was not licensed at the time she interviewed Child,
  although she was undergoing the licensing process.Â  Consequently, Childâ€™s
  hearsay statements to Dr. Reyes were inadmissible.Â  
Finally,
  Father contends Dr. Reyes improperly commented on Childâ€™s credibility by saying
  Child â€œhad no apparent motivation . . . to have a false allegation,â€ and Child
  gave a â€œconsistent disclosure.â€Â  For a psychologist
  to comment on the veracity of a childâ€™s accusations of sexual abuse is improper.Â  State v. Dawkins, 297 S.C. 386, 393-94, 377 S.E.2d 298, 302 (1989) (finding
  therapist indicating he believed victimâ€™s allegations were genuine was improper); see also State v. Dempsey, 340 S.C. 565, 571, 532 S.E.2d 306, 309
  (Ct. App. 2000) (finding therapistâ€™s testimony children were being truthful in
  ninety-five percent of instances in which sexual abuse was alleged was improper
  vouching for child).
In
  the instant case, Father made no contemporaneous objection when Dr. Reyes
  testified Child had no reason to make a false allegation and Child did not
  appear to have been coached.Â  Consequently, any error regarding those specific
  comments as to truthfulness is not preserved.Â  See State v. Hoffman,
  312 S.C. 386, 393, 440 S.E.2d 869, 873 (1994) (holding a contemporaneous
  objection is required to preserve an issue for appellate review).Â  
However,
  Father did object to Dr. Reyesâ€™ testifying Child gave a â€œconsistent disclosure
  about her putting a card in her vaginal area bitting [sic] her butt and putting
  a car in her rectum.â€Â  In the recent case of State v. Douglas, 367 S.C.
  498, 505, 626 S.E.2d 59, 63 (2006) cert. granted, June 7, 2007, a
  witness, Herod, qualified as an expert in forensic interviewing of sexual
  assault victims, testified that after interviewing a child she recommended a
  medical exam.Â  Douglas argued this testimony improperly bolstered the Stateâ€™s
  case as it would lead a jury to believe the expert considered childâ€™s accusations
  truthful.Â  This court concluded: â€œAlthough the jury could infer Herod thought
  the victim told her the truth about being molested, . . . Herod did not express
  her opinion as to whether or not the victim told her the truth during the
  interview.â€Â  Id. at 522, 626 S.E.2d at 72.Â  Consequently, Herodâ€™s
  testimony did not improperly comment on the childâ€™s credibility.
In
  contrast, in this case, Dr. Reyes indicated Child gave a consistent disclosure
  and that as a result of that conclusion she recommended therapy.Â  Dr. Reyesâ€™
  testimony seems fill the inferential gap that made Herodâ€™s testimony in Douglas admissible.Â  There is little doubt Dr. Reyes found Childâ€™s testimony to be
  credible, and testimony to that effect is inadmissible.[5] Â 
B. Motherâ€™s Testimony
Father
  contends the family court erred in allowing Mother to testify regarding Childâ€™s
  accusations against Father.Â  The family court concluded part (G) of the statute
  did not prohibit the introduction of such statements because Child made them to
  Mother prior to Mother and Fatherâ€™s separation.Â  Part (G) states the â€œhearsay statement shall be inadmissible if (1) one of the parents
  is the alleged perpetrator of the alleged abuse or neglect and (2) the allegation was made after the parties separated or divorced.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  Because
  the statute is considering the
  hearsay statement by the child, allegation could refer to the statement by
  Child to Mother.Â  However, allegation could also refer to the repetition of
  Childâ€™s hearsay statement by Mother at the hearing.
If a
  statute is susceptible to two reasonable interpretations, it is ambiguous.Â  See Sloan v. S.C. Bd. of Physical Therapy Examâ€™rs, 370 S.C. 452, 489, 636
  S.E.2d 598, 617 (2006) (Toal, C.J., dissenting).Â  When â€œa statute is ambiguous,
  the Court must construe the terms of the statute.â€Â  Wade v. Berkeley County, 348 S.C. 224, 229, 559 S.E.2d 586,588 (2002).Â  As previously stated, the cardinal rule of statutory construction is to discern
  and give effect to the intent of the legislature.Â  Hodges, 341 S.C. at
  85, 533 S.E.2d at 581.Â  â€œAll rules of statutory construction are subservient to
  the one that the legislative intent must prevail if it can be reasonably
  discovered in the language used, and that language must be construed in light
  of the intended purpose of the statute.â€Â  Broadhurst v. City of Myrtle Beach Election Commâ€™n, 342 S.C. 373, 380, 537 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000). 
As discussed above, the purpose of part (G) of the statute is to
  protect a parent from potentially false accusations instigated by the other parent.Â  In this case, to allow Mother to testify
  after the separation regarding statements made before the separation undermines
  the purpose of this part.Â  In promoting false allegations, a parent could simply
  claim allegations were made by the child prior to separation simply to evade
  the purview of the statute.Â  Part (G) protects against accusations potentially
  arising from the acrimony of separation; therefore, if the witness is
  testifying after the separation the danger for false allegations still exists.Â 
  Consequently, we conclude the admission of Childâ€™s hearsay statement to Mother
  was error.
C. Detective
  Bellâ€™s Testimony
Father
  contends the family court erred in allowing Detective Bell to testify regarding
  Childâ€™s hearsay statements.Â  We disagree. Â As discussed with regard to Dr.
  Reyesâ€™ testimony, Child was available to testify so that Childâ€™s hearsay
  statements were admissible under (B)(1).Â  There is no argument that Detective
  Bellâ€™s testimony should have been excluded under part (G) as she clearly falls
  with the category of law enforcement official.
Father
  also appeals the admission of Detective Bellâ€™s testimony that the Sheriffâ€™s
  Department had â€œprobable causeâ€ to keep open its criminal investigation of
  Father.Â  Fatherâ€™s objection at trial and on appeal is based on relevance.Â  Rule
  401 of the South Carolina Rules of Evidence defines relevant evidence as â€œevidence having any tendency to make the existence of
  any fact that is of consequence to the determination of the action more
  probable or less probable than it would be without the evidence.â€ Â In the instant case, Detective Bellâ€™s opinion the criminal
  case should remain open does not make any specific fact of consequence more or
  less probable.Â  
Furthermore,
  even if Detective Bellâ€™s opinion was relevant, all relevant evidence is not
  admissible.Â  â€œ[T]he dictates
  of Rule 401 are subject to the balancing requirement of Rule 403, SCRE, which
  requires a court to exclude relevant evidence upon a showing that its admission
  would be more prejudicial than probative.â€ Â Jamison v. Ford Motor Co.,
  373 S.C. 248, 269, 644 S.E.2d 755, 766 (Ct. App. 2007) (quoting Watson ex rel. Watson v. Chapman, 343 S.C. 471, 478, 540 S.E.2d 484, 487
  (Ct. App. 2000)); see also Rule 403,
  SCRE (â€œAlthough relevant, evidence
  may be excluded if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the
  danger of unfair prejudice, confusion of the issues, or misleading the jury, or
  by considerations of undue delay, waste of time, or needless presentation of
  cumulative evidence.â€).Â  
In
  the present case, nothing indicates the family court conducted a prejudicial
  versus probative analysis.Â  Evidence is unfairly prejudicial in the context of
  Rule 403, if the evidence has an undue tendency to suggest a decision on an
  improper basis, such as an emotional one.Â  State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114,
  127, 551 S.E.2d 240, 247 (2001).Â  In this case, Detective Bellâ€™s testimony
  suggests Father is guilty of sexual misconduct against Child and is highly
  prejudicial.Â  For the fact-finder to make a determination based on the
  Detectiveâ€™s opinion of guilt would be improper.Â  Therefore, we conclude the
  admission of this evidence was error.Â Â Â Â  
D. Dr. Tonkawitzâ€™s Testimony
Father
  also claims the family court erred in admitting pediatrician Dr. Tonkawitzâ€™s
  testimony the history provided by Mother when Child was brought for examination
  was â€œconvincing.â€Â  We agree.Â  As previously discussed, an expert is not to
  comment on the veracity of another witnessâ€™s statements.Â  Dawkins, 297
  S.C. at 393-94, 377 S.E.2d at 302; Dempsey, 340 S.C. at 571, 532 S.E.2d at
  309.Â  Tonkawitz should not have been
  allowed to give her opinion as to Motherâ€™s truthfulness regarding Childâ€™s
  medical history.Â  Such observation is reserved for the trier of fact, in this
  case, the family court. See S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Forrester,
  282 S.C. 512, 516, 320 S.E.2d 39, 42 (Ct. App. 1984) (â€œThe credibility of
  testimony is a matter for the finder of fact to judge.â€).Â Â Â Â  
II. Shifting of
  Burden of Proof
Father contends the family court shifted the burden of
  proof, requiring him to prove his innocence.Â  In a DSS intervention case, DSS has
  the burden of proof by the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Aiken County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Wilcox, 304 S.C. 90, 93, 403 S.E.2d
  142, 143 (1991).Â  The family courtâ€™s order addresses the defense put forth by
  Father including the negative psychological testing for pedophilic tendencies
  and Childâ€™s negative physical examination.Â  The family court concluded this
  evidence could not rule out the possibility of sexual abuse.Â  This language is
  somewhat problematic, but viewing the order as a whole, the family court relied
  upon the evidence presented by DSS in reaching its conclusion.Â  The order
  enumerates the testimony of the witnesses indicating Child made disclosures of
  abuse as well as considering Childâ€™s demeanor on the witness stand.Â  Furthermore,
  the order cites to evidence showing Child was acting out sexually and was
  experiencing nightmares.Â  Overall, it does not appear the family court
  impermissibly shifted the burden to Father.Â  The order simply addresses all of
  the evidence put forth before it including Fatherâ€™s and Childâ€™s negative test
  results.
CONCLUSION
We conclude the
  admission of Childâ€™s hearsay statements through Dr. Reyes was erroneous in
  light of section 19-1-180(G).Â  We find
  comments by Dr. Reyes regarding Childâ€™s credibility were likewise inadmissible.Â 
  Furthermore, Motherâ€™s testimony regarding Childâ€™s hearsay statements was also inadmissible
  under section 19-1-180(G).Â  Additionally, comments by Dr. Tonkawitz regarding
  Motherâ€™s credibility were inadmissible.Â  Finally, the admission of Detective
  Bellâ€™s opinion as to probable cause in Fatherâ€™s criminal case was error.Â  The
  sum of these errors warrants reversal of the family courtâ€™s order.Â  This case
  is therefore
REVERSED
  AND REMANDED.
ANDERSON
AND WILLIAMS, J.J., concur. 


[1] Before we begin our analysis, we emphasize this case
  involves the interpretation of a very specific statute dealing with the
  introduction of a childâ€™s hearsay statements in the context of a DSS
  intervention action.Â  Any conclusions should be strictly ascribed to the
  application of this statute and should not be extrapolated with respect to the
admission or exclusion of hearsay statements in the criminal context.
[2] Dr. Reyes described a problematic non-disclosure as
  an interview in which a child may deny improper touching, but there are
problems with the way the child answers the questions.Â  
[3] Testimony revealed Child referred to the restaurant
Chick-Fil-A as the cow place.
[4] Father raises issues that apply to the testimony of
  several different witnesses.Â  For the sake of organization we will address each
witnessâ€™ testimony in turn and each argument related thereto.
[5] We note Dr. Reyes was never actually qualified as an
  expert in either clinical psychology or forensic interviewing although such a
  motion was made and her experience and education were presented to the family
court.Â  Her status as an expert is not raised on appeal.
